												I love this game. I've never played any actual X-COM games since most of them came out before I was even born so for those of you who want that sort of view point read another review I suppose. Anyways, so far as I'm concerned this is a really great turn-based strategy and while the graphics/animations aren't that great in themselves they are crisp and clean enough when paired with the music and sound to create a very immersive experience. In fact the immersion is really my only complaint about this game, that complaint being that it is too immersive. Seriously. The sound and music of this game is just ♥♥♥♥ing incredible. It really makes you feel like the entirety of humanity is completly screwed cause these aliens with their super advanced technology are here to wreck♥♥♥♥♥♥and kill. Not to mention how attached you get to your soilders. Had this one that had seen some real♥♥♥♥♥♥and been with us since the very beginning with no small number of kills and in one move I killed her. I had her run up to a corner and hide behind some crates then I clicked "end turn" and a reaper came around the corner stabbed her and boom turned her into a zombie. In just 3 seconds I had just lost my most experienced and well equiped soilder all because I thought those crates looked like a safe place to hide. The sound she made when she died didn't help either nor the fact that I had to kill her zombified self. It was really quite heartbreaking. This game is immersive and depressing, it will make you contemplate the meaning life, question if anything really matters, and it will keep you coming back 'cause ♥♥♥♥ those alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s welcome to Earf.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Look at all these crazy video games about alien invasions!!! There are many ways you can waste aliens from the comfort of your slowly flattening computer chair. What's Xenonauts all about then? Oh, it's a remake of the original XCOM: Enemy Unknown!Like the original XCOM, aliens invade, you shoot the aliens in the face, etc. Also like the original XCOM: It takes the ♥♥♥♥ing scenic route!!! Seeing through a game of Xenonauts will take a long, long time, and a lot of the time spent will occur in ground combat, where the idiots you're guiding through the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥town or the ♥♥♥♥ forest will need constant adjustment in order not to get blown up (and during the early game, your dudes will get blown up as much as the ones you're shooting, because this game is balls hard. Even on Normal.). The scenic route is made even more scenic-ier, because all the missions start to bleed through and look the same. It's not all tedium - the game allows you to walk into the enemy's UFO, kill everyone inside, and hold it for five turns to win the mission automatically, which is a nice touch. The game is all about destructible environments, so you can take a squad of fast-moving shotgunners, blow a hole in the side of the UFO with a rocket launcher, and win a mission that way. There's all these neat little additions that fit nicely with the original's ethos (saving AP for return fire on aliens dumb enough to wander into firing range). There's also a few unconventional ones to make gameplay less pedantic and fussy, such as allowing unlimited flares on night missions. The developers COULD have not included them, making night missions extremely sucktacular engagements due to a very short LOS and with one soldier having to leave his gun in the dropship to be 'the guy who throws lights everywhere who is shot from behind by some extra-terrestrial ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hiding in a tree'. But they did, and you can throw as many as you want. Yay!So it's kind of bland and it goes on for a long while (a campaign run is in the 50-100 hour ballpark). But it's a neat take on XCOM-style play, and mods are being added by the community to hammer out flaws. It's not going to replace the 2012 XCOM for me, but if you're looking for an update that captures the original very well, give this a shot.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												After almost 110 hours of gameplay time, I cannot recommend this game.Let's start with the pros. The air battles are interesting. They certainly are an upgrade to the original XCOM. Unfortunatly, there very few cases where you would want to manually resolve them. Once you reach mid-game, you will in most cases use the autoresolve feature. The kick for playing another XCOM can be a plus if you are a nostalgic.Cons include:* Limited enemies variety. They get stronger, they get more hitpoints and armor but they are just the same.* In about 70% of the cases, your soldiers will die in a single hit. This highly limits all your strategic choices in ground battles.* Still quite a few bugs are present. Mission objectives are wrong, trees appear in ships, soldier can go off map limits, impossible line of sight are visible, there is an annoying looping walking sound effect bug from some standing enemy.* There is a just a single overall strategy: get air superiority ASAP. It is almost impossible to lose once you get it and you can achieve it early on in the game.* Good base locations are limited. There is a pattern that you must follow.* Limited maps variety. You will see them once and you will see them again and again.* Tedious grind. Research is slow and painful. You will be facing many of the same alien waves before you progress and nothing important seems to be happening during that time.* AI is predictable and quite dumb. It won't be looking to get into cover that much, it will always target the solider that is easier to hit, it will only use grenades when you are grouped. It does not try to flank you.* Vehicles are mostly useless. They are often limited to the surrounding area around the dropship because they are too big to go anywhere. They replace 2 soldiers and they are only worth like 1.2 soldier. In the end, you will not be using them. They do not offer enough strategic possibilities.Only buy the game if you are a huge fanatic of the XCOM series, turn-based games, you played them all and the game is on sale.

number of helpful: 28 of 55 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												I like old UFO games and I like the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and EW add on and LW mod). I like tactical games. I like turn based games.And I really tried to like Xenonauts. I tried to like it because in theory it's a great game and because I wanted to justify spending money on it. But I couldn't.EVERYTHING in this game is crappy. The first jarring thing is air combat. While in theory very good, it's just too bugged. About 5-10% of my air fights end up in my and enemy aircrafts circling around each other forever at the same spot, and if I try to move my plane it's an obvious suicide, so I can either do that or alt+F4. Other than this annoyance air combat is fine as it is, however, it's much better to just hit autoresolve and spare yourself some irritation from time to time. The next extremely annoying thing is a field of vision of soldiers. It seems they are are incredibly shortsighted to a point they can't see anything over 10 meters away and miss targets that are five meters away by fvkking miles. The best tactic is to run at enemies to stand one meter away from them as in melee fight and then shoot them because otherwise your dvmb♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t4rded soldier will miss or even perhaps kill one of the other squad members shooting in a wrong direction by a 90 degrees. In addition, while the player is walking around the maps almost blindly, aliens always know where the player's units are. Even if they are on the other side of the map they already see you. So skreew you if you wanted to use a short vision against the enemy. The next thing is that aliens just love "camping". A bunch of them will just sit in their aircraft with a closed door (so far I did not find a way to just blow upthe whole aircrafts with those t4rrds inside) and wait for you. If you run a soldier over there, they will murder him and close the door. In consequence you just put a bunch of soldiers around  the door, run with one tw4t through the fvkken door and get him shredded due to aliens' reaction fire and then shoot everything inside with the rest of the squad. Every fight same tactics. It's repetitive and boring.While your guys can't shoot anything 5 meters away, aliens seem to have better aim, but that's not even very noticeable. What is very noticeable is that sometimes they shoot from twice your vision or through walls which are impenetrable for your guys. Ultimate trolls.It's also funny to see a fully armored combat vehicle to explode into pieces after a "bullet" from the enemy's gun hits it. It looks like a tank exploding after being shot by a gun. Why, what I don't even... either don't put such vehicles in the game if they seem too powerful or make them very expensive, but why put such a vehicle only to be as easily destroyed as a random soldier? Especially when the vehicle takes 6 slots, meaning you could put 6 soldiers on its place? Sure, it has a very powerful gun, but so what if it gets destroyed withing a few rounds.The game also crashes like crazy on Linux. Loading new map... crash. Air combat... crash. New round... crash. I do not recommend this game to anyone. It's a waste of money, time and nerves. If you like old XCOM/UFO, then just play them or go ahead with the modern casualized version that is XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, which is still a great game on its own. Try out the Long War for more fun. But for your own good stay the heck away from a tvrrd that is Xenonauts. I wasted money that would buy me a few sacks of potatoes or some burgers, do not make the same mistake. Actually, don't even buy it when this game will get cheap and hits -75% sales. It's just unplayable.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Why go throught all the trouble of making such a realistic remake if it is to break all the realism by making the earth flat ?The original XCOM had it all right, the earth was a sphere.  And I'm not just speaking about the type of map projection used, I'm talking about the way aircrafts are travelling, the way radar ranges are depicted and things like that.I don't feel like I'm defending a planet, I feel like I'm defending a flat table with a distorted map drawn on it, or more accurately a cylinder since the map connects on the sides.In this game, on the ''flat map'' globe, the radar ranges are circular, no matter where you are on the globe, well they should'nt, the range of the radar should be factored for the fact that it's a flat map, it should widen towards the poles, otherwise the map is all wrong.  Every aircraft travel in a straight line, just like if the earth was flat, well they should'nt.  The map is distorted, and so are the trajectories and distances.  Now what would be the advantage of putting a base on the north pole, since the distances are so wrong when you consider the earth as a cylinder with very wide poles.  For example, in real life, the shortest route from the southern tip of Chile to Australia doesn't involve going all the way on a due east trajetory, it should be trought the south pole.  ( Where is the south pole anyway in this game ? )  By using such an unrealistic approach to the ''globe'' aspect of the game, it really breaks a big aspect for anybody who liked managing strategically the globe part in XCOM.  Once again, the original game from 20 years ago had it all correct, why change that ?Don't get me wrong, I'm going to recommend this game to any XCOM fan.  XCOM was one of the greatest game of all times and any attempts at bringing back some memories of it should be funded and encouraged.  This remake is an excellent game, with one unnecessary big flaw in my opinion.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												I did not play the old X-com games, but I did play the new one, so that will be my frame of reference in this.To me, this game feels like XCOM:EU bashed together artfully with Jagged Alliance 2 - it's got the depth, graphic style, and sometimes gameplay of JA, with the basic concepts and more modern feel of XCOM. The UI is also somewhat JA style, but has been streamlined enough that it reminds me more of Fallout 2's UI. Like XCOM, it has managed to do away with the tedious, forced micromanagement of JA and other games of that period, but does also seem to reward it a bit if you want to take the time to mess with the details, and has made doing so much easier than games from the period this one is trying to emulate.Yeah, reading that sure makes this game sound derivative, doesn't it?That's because it is, and proudly so. And what's wrong with that? Why wouldn't I want a game that looks good enough. lets me tweak things as much or as little as I want, and plays and feels like some of the best games ever?If you are into shiney graphics and found hard difficulty XCOM:EU to be fun and challenging enough, then don't bother with this - the normal difficulty is generally a little more difficult than hard EU.  If you thought it was a great game, but just lacking something to make it a real 700 hour monster time eater, then you should really check this out. If you liked Jagged Alliance or it's modern clone, then you'll love this - it plays very similarly, and the RNG, LOS, and other mechanics are less broken. If liked the quirky gameplay of Fallout 1 and 2 and the darkly comical world, then you'll probably like this, but if you found the combat there overwhelmingly hard, then you might not.One more quick little note: If you haven't played any of the above, but want to get into this sort of games, this is a good place to start. Unlike most of them, the easy mode is actually easy enough fora brand new player to get the swing of things, but becomes challenging enough to be worth playing through to the late game.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												You could call Xenonauts a truly faithful remake of the orginial classic Xcom: UFO Defense but is it actually any good or is it just a poor attempt at capturing that unique Xcom feeling like some many games have tried?It's absolutely great! Despite having some minor flaws.Xenonauts is basically a modernised and up-to date version of the classic with it's own little twists and features. Where Xenonauts excels is that it's just a really enjoyable experience. First of all the aesthetics might look pretty bland but they fit the game quite well and everything looks extremely sharp and detailed. There is a lot of great artwork and sprites in this game. The soundtrack totally enhances the threating atmosphere and truly immerses yourself into the game.The gameplay mechanics are mostly identical except that they improved the interface and user-friendlyness. The classic Xcom had a lot of tedious micromanagement and a cumbersome interface. I never particularly enjoyed the logistics aspect of the classic. Xenonauts has a great interface that conveys information in a great manner. Equiping soldiers and manageing your base is far better. The research tree is great aswell and the descriptions add a lot of flavor to the game.The tactical turn-based ground battles are intense and quite challenging thanks to the multitude of difficulties that you can choose from. The geoscape section is also greatly enhanced, the aliens won't hesistate to launch a full scale assault and there is far more to do on the geoscape than in the classic. They also add some nifty new options and events like local military fighting against the aliens as well and airstriking downed ufos.There is much to talk about in this game but I'll keep it short for now, it's a great game for fans of the classics or turn-based games. I definitely recommend it.The only negative aspects that come to mind is that there aren't that many maps, you will often see the same layouts during the battles. Luckily there is a huge mappack available on the official forums that adds tons of detailed and varied maps.Also sometimes the tactical battles can be a bit fiddly on tight spaces and the cover system can be confusing at times, the line of sight works really well but at times it's confusing as well. But once you play for a while you get the hang of it.

												Too much to discuss here really but I recommend it. I never would have bought it for the full price so I'm glad it showed up in a bundle. I've never played X-com or enemy unknown so I don't have good points of comparison, but I can tell you the basics. Pros:-First dozen times I tried to play: extremely difficult. I'm having fun on easy mode still, not getting destroyed at every corner. -The writing is great, minimal story but its told in a cool way. Great mythos and some great mystery elements. Cons:-Difficulty, maybe I play too "run and gun" but I seem to get murdered on anythign but easy mode. -FOV is a little silly and night missions just make it even more so. Sometimes you can turn a corner, and unless you are facing the exact direction, you can get shot in the side of the head. IRL, people can see to the side, even if only slightly.-I wish there were achievements-I wish auto saves self-labeled and didn't overwrite. It would be nice to have auto check points since the difficulty can be so unforgiving sometimes.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Much, MUCH like the 90's classic X-Com. Once you dive in, you'll see it.The difference is the tech trees, discriptions, maps, aliens (beings, ships, weapons, ect). Their motivations are the same, plus the planet Earth, but the interface is quite improved.You have pretty much total control - planning bases, troop management, improvements, mission planning -  the whole shebang. As you progress, the aliens get more numerous, dangerous, larger, more aggressive, and your apprehensions can get the best of you. Only downside is the end game - it was a tad gamey (maybe even letdown), expected something harder ala the old X-Com. Was fun, though....There is ample mod support - The Commuinty Edition is widely played, and tweaks many of the standard game to enhance the experence, and is endorsed by the producer, and hosts a lively forum. Pretty darned impressive...Been following this for a while, and it dropped off my radar, but quite glad it did not become vaporware. Great purchace, fantastic community, and heavily supported.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												I never got the chance to play the original X-Com.  I heard the legends, of course, of all the things it did right that no other game (incuding newer X-Com titles) had managed: the perfect balance of weapons and gear so that every type of loadout has its use, the punishing yet fair difficulty (the aliens are stronger than you, but it's always possible to beat them), the general sense of dread at every crash site, the amazing metagame of base building and resource allocation across continents, and so many other features that added up to an amazing, tense, immersive, and satisfying experience.I cannot say if Xenonauts is as good as X-Com, or how the two compare, but I can say this: Xenonauts does everything right.  It sounds crazy to say, but it's true.  The balance of both your equipment and enemies', especially with the latest patches and Community Edition, is perfect.  Both the metagame and tactical encounters are complex and satisfying.  Every choice, every action has weight, tension, and immense significance to your war with the alien threat.  Battles are tense, tactics are paramount; your soldiers' survival is tenuous, but if you use the right tactics, there is hope.So, I cannot say if Xenonauts is as good as X-Com was, but I can say that it is as good as X-Com's hype, which is even more impressive.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												8.5/10Buy at: $10"Really fun. Great balance. Challenging but not unfairly so. Late 90s graphics. No multiplayer."PRO:You can abduct aliens by emptying a character's backpack and stuffing an alien inside. Very well balanced play. A tremendous number of viable strategies. Very good pacing. Challenging, but doesn't take cheap shots. Sometimes your ground units will get their asses handed to them. It's immersive and addictive like a Sid Meier title, and has a great amount of background material (Xenopedia) to give it serious depth. There's a level editor and basic modding tools included. The music and ambient audio work well with the game.CON:Air-to-air combat is too easy. The ground combat graphics are bland and somewhat dated. There's no multiplayer mode (!?!?!!?).

But if your luck is worse than mine then you might just lose the whole game just because your Xenonauts can't defend against Psi attacks and guess what unlike an Xcom Warrior, Xenonauts can't learn Psionics so you would have to rely on either bravery or Mods to protect them from the attacks.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												For those who loved X-Com: UFO Defense/UFO: Enemy Unknown and want to have roughly the same experience as that 20+ year old game with the benefits of modern technology, then this is the game for you. Big battles, multiple bases, and a pretty severe difficulty. But there is new stuff too, like a better interface, a variety of neat toys to use against the aliens, and much more. On the downside, It can get a bit repetitive over time as you send a team to clear out yet another UFO you shot down, but I guess that just adds to the atmosphere of an endless conflict where you are badly outnumbered and outgunned. But you can fix that in time, of course. Still, this game will eat up alot of time, so be prepared for a major time commitment if you are planning on playing this to the end.Save the world from the aliens! Yey.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I was excited about this release back in 2013 but for many reasons have not gotten around to it until recently. I don't have a lot of hours in yet but all I can say is WOW. This is the most faithful reproduction of X-COM: Enemy Unknown by a wide, wide margin - and that's no knock on the recent reboot by Firaxis; they are simply dramatically different games. Xeno distinguishes itself with the faithful depth and unforgiving, unapologetic tactical harshness that is carried by poor or reckless decision making. It is amazing that we have both XCOM and Xeno, and that they are both such great games and I found a fantastic article below by Phil Hartup that dives so well in to exaclty this topic and provides an excellent history of what the franchise has gone through. Absolutely worth the time to read if your exposure to the franchise is rooted larely in the recent reboot, and if you loved the classic from 1994 and have, like so many of us, given up hope of a faithful reproduction after decades of disappointment - this is a slam-dunk to run long nights in to the dawn.http://www.newstatesman.com/killing-time/2013/10/xcom-enemy-unknown-xenonauts-dumbed-down-game-any-less-fun

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Why go throught all the trouble of making such a realistic remake if it is to break all the realism by making the earth flat ?The original XCOM had it all right, the earth was a sphere.  And I'm not just speaking about the type of map projection used, I'm talking about the way aircrafts are travelling, the way radar ranges are depicted and things like that.I don't feel like I'm defending a planet, I feel like I'm defending a flat table with a distorted map drawn on it, or more accurately a cylinder since the map connects on the sides.In this game, on the ''flat map'' globe, the radar ranges are circular, no matter where you are on the globe, well they should'nt, the range of the radar should be factored for the fact that it's a flat map, it should widen towards the poles, otherwise the map is all wrong.  Every aircraft travel in a straight line, just like if the earth was flat, well they should'nt.  The map is distorted, and so are the trajectories and distances.  Now what would be the advantage of putting a base on the north pole, since the distances are so wrong when you consider the earth as a cylinder with very wide poles.  For example, in real life, the shortest route from the southern tip of Chile to Australia doesn't involve going all the way on a due east trajetory, it should be trought the south pole.  ( Where is the south pole anyway in this game ? )  By using such an unrealistic approach to the ''globe'' aspect of the game, it really breaks a big aspect for anybody who liked managing strategically the globe part in XCOM.  Once again, the original game from 20 years ago had it all correct, why change that ?Don't get me wrong, I'm going to recommend this game to any XCOM fan.  XCOM was one of the greatest game of all times and any attempts at bringing back some memories of it should be funded and encouraged.  This remake is an excellent game, with one unnecessary big flaw in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really love & hate this game. The entire premise is fantastic. What I really hate is that aircombat is frustratingly stupid (fighters won't fire their missiles even when they have a lock sometimes). Ground combat has the oddity of even seasoned soldiers overreacting and shooting your own guys when they see an alien. These buggy bits could be argued to be realistic... but only slightly. Also everytime your soldiers are in sick bay and then come back they conveniently forget all the items they were carrying into battle before. I know you can make new roles... but it's all a huge pain in the rear.You can't lob a friggin grenade anywhere you can't visually see... which is pretty much how grenades are supposed to be used.The ultimate armored suit doesn't seem to be that effective (pretty sure my guy gets hurt just as much in that thing as out of it.Berserking is stupid... your guy will decide to turn around and shoot his own people.Also... no one warned me you could lose countries and not gain them back. Even though the death toll only states there's a few thousand killed. It makes no sense unless the aliens really did cleanse the earth in those places, which they didn't.This has the makings of a great game. Xenonauts 2 will hopefully improve upon this because the idea is really really great in conception but not execution. Just too many frustrating things (especially the combat that leaves a 95% burst with 0 rounds impacting on target) Also the heavy machine gun should carry about 200 rounds per drum... but you only have 30 rounds per.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												"When it comes down to it, “Xenonauts” is a challenging and at times, gut-wrenching experience…especially if you’re a perfectionist like me.  Watching each one of my soldiers die was a painful reminder of just how unforgiving this game can be.  On the other hand, it makes victory taste all the sweeter.  It’s currently priced at $24.99 (as of 6/19/14), which is a good deal all things considered.  When you consider the amount of play time you’ll spend on one playthru (twenty to forty hours on average), you’ll realize that you’re getting a lot of bang for your buck.  The “XCOM” Firaxis/2K Games remake originally retailed for fifty to sixty bucks, just to put things in perspective.  This game IS worth your time and money, though those who get easily frustrated by difficult games should probably remove all breakables from their immediately vicinity before playing."Full Review: http://www.dadsgamingaddiction.com/xenonauts/

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												8.5/10Buy at: $10"Really fun. Great balance. Challenging but not unfairly so. Late 90s graphics. No multiplayer."PRO:You can abduct aliens by emptying a character's backpack and stuffing an alien inside. Very well balanced play. A tremendous number of viable strategies. Very good pacing. Challenging, but doesn't take cheap shots. Sometimes your ground units will get their asses handed to them. It's immersive and addictive like a Sid Meier title, and has a great amount of background material (Xenopedia) to give it serious depth. There's a level editor and basic modding tools included. The music and ambient audio work well with the game.CON:Air-to-air combat is too easy. The ground combat graphics are bland and somewhat dated. There's no multiplayer mode (!?!?!!?).

												I'm a huge, HUGE fane of the original X-Com.  I was really looking foward to this game and hoped an indie company could restore the glorius gameplay that was X-com -- but they fall short.They really try to be true to the source material, but nothing quite meshes.  Graphics and animations are meh and the A.I. still makes those magical shots from 300 yards away, around the tree, under the car, through the two house windows -- killing your soldier instantly.  On the other end of the spectrum, you will miss the alien standing next to you, with a plasma shot gun and 99% CTH -- and if you are lucky enough to hit it, it will take a whopping 5% damage, while the other 7 of your soldiers will panic, drop their gun, and run right up to the enemies for a merciful quick killing.It's very frustrating, to say the least.  So close, but so far.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												FINAL RELEASE REVIEW: This review was originally a negative review. It turned into a positive one, and now it's negative. Prepare for a rant.Xenonauts still feels like it's in beta. Civilian A.I is stupid. You can't tell them to stay put; they still run around like idiots and get killed. The game pretends the aliens have moved. A lot of the time, you won't be able to see an alien after your team JUST took potshots at it. You will have to move up a squadmate (wasting that soldier's TU) so that you can see the alien again, which has not moved. The game's rendering system is RIDICULOUS. Here's an example: I activated C4 on the front door of an alien ship. The turn ended. The area where the fire should have been was dark. It seemed like the C4 failed. I brought my soldier up and he walked into fire that didn't even render until he stepped on it. Seriously? Also, if you have your tank (hunter scout car) blow up in front of the UFO doors, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. You can't open the doors, shoot through the tank, get on top of it, or push it away. The animations are lacking severely. The doors just snap; there isn't any cool animation of their opening. The geoscape takes a bizarre amount of time to load, too. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing PICTURE, not some 3D holographic image from XCOM: Enemy Unknown. The soldiers are ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ too. Am I hiring my family members and people off the street to join my organization or something? Like I said, this game still feels like it's in beta.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.comIf you were looking for the spiritual successor to the X-Com franchise, Xenonauts feels like the game you’ve been waiting for. Even though The Buraeu: X-Com Declassified and Enemy Unknown/Within were great games in their own right, they just didn’t quite capture the same feeling that the classic games had. While some things need to evolve and change, there’s something to be said about making a recipe with most of the same ingredients to enjoy the meal you remember. (That’s especially true if they are going to say that it tastes similar.) I covered a lot of the basics of this game in the X-Com: Enemy Unknown VS. Xenonauts review so I’m not going to cover everything since Goldhawk Interactive finished up everything that needed fixing to transition from Early Access to Launch status pretty smoothly.Let’s start with difficulty shall we? That was a trademark aspect of the originals. (I still can’t complete TFTD.) I started Xenonauts on the Regular difficulty and had both starter interceptor planes shot down in one-on-one dogfights. (At which point I had nothing to shoot down enemy aircraft.) The enemy craft ended up landing after downing my two aircraft giving me my first mission… out of pity. During the pity mission (which happened to be a night mission of course) I had lost two soldiers before I got ten spaces from my Chinook from enemies I couldn’t see. Needless to say I started over and changed the difficulty to easy. I usually don’t like playing games on easy, but this game just kicked me in the nuts and laughed in my face.Thinking that the game was going to be too easy after the difficulty was changed was a bad assumption on my part. That little dead alien in the corner reminded me that I shouldn’t let my guard down. This little bugger skirted around the edge of the map taking pot shots at my guys almost killing two of them. I was throwing out flares left and right to try to find him to no avail. I eventually found him by sending one soldier randomly to the side of the map and just happened to spot him. Needless to say, when he became visible, the bullets went flying.Moving on, research has been overhauled to be more convenient for the player. Let’s just say that you go out on your first mission and you clean house very well. When you get back to base you have only a few options to research, general concepts like alien electronics or alien interrogations if you managed to capture an alien alive. What about the dissections and the alien craft that you left behind? Well, it’s being taken cared of. That’s being done behind the scenes and you’ll get that info in good time and the other related research options therein. You still have plenty of things to research so don’t feel robbed here; Xenonauts makes research feel streamlined.Another interesting note is that wounded soldiers heal more realistically. This is a neat update while at the same time pretty frustrating. I liked it when people just took a few days off and then poof they were combat ready and good-as-new. In Xenonauts they take time to become combat ready with reduced stats and even more time to fully recover. When the number of days are up for your soldier to enter the field again, they are given a percentage of how much they’ve recovered. You’ll have less health to run around with and lose when you get shot. As time goes on, they do get better, but that’s with time.There are plenty of different looking locals between deserts, desert bases, towns, farms and enemy bases. They have different maps for the same type as well so you’ll never really feel that “you’ve been here before”. That is a very nice feature, because few things feel as cheap than reused levels. Some may call the graphic choice dated, but not only does it look nice aesthetically, the devs do a great job setting a creepy atmosphere with it. I really like the presentation of Xenonauts.One last note, the NPCs in Xenonauts are freaking amazing. Some are just helpless civilians and do stupid civilian things, but the guys with guns (soldiers and farmers) actually use thier guns to defend themselves. I’ve had some levels be finished by some random farmer killing an alien before my guys got to the part of the map. Well played Goldhawk Interactive, well played.Score: Tasty!There is a lot to love here for fans of tactical games. Nothing feels rushed and sometimes that’s a concern people have when games come out of Early Access. It’s all smooth running and gunning here. With the varied locals and very nice looking isometric scenery, there is some really good “retro” (if you want to call it that) eye-candy to be had. Goldenhawk Interactive doesn’t go out of their way to revamp the series with light blooms and next-gen graphics. They pull from what made the originals so great and modernize it. I have nothing bad to say about Xenonauts (especially since they allow me to lower the difficulty setting). I will try a harder difficulty later, but as of now I appreciate having my ego padded a little more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												As a huge fan of Turn Based Strategy games, and being raised on X-Com (Still own the floppy discs) I have to say if you're looking for a spiritual successor to the original games this one matches it the closest.If you're familiar with the original X-Coms this game will seem very familiar to you. The game falls into two categories of gameplay. A globe you must monitor, while in this "Geoscape" the world will go through day and night cycles. During this time you can set scientists to research, Workers to manufacture, and slowly build from a tiny strike force into a globe encompassing powerhouse as you aquire more and more alien technology and information of what they are doing on earth. The key to this part of the game, is sending out fighters to have aerial battles in a very neat radar style where you move your fighters around to position for maximum effectiveness, or to eventually touch down your transport vehicles to enter the next stage of the game.The second part is where the core of the gameplay lies. A turn based isometric game. Rather than diverging away from the original and giving them 2 actions like the new X-Coms. Characters have AP, meaning all of your abilities must be carefully calculated for the perfect shot or just to hope you can run far enough away after missing and shouting out loud at your computer.  These points can also be used for a variety of abilities, from weaponry to alien technologies.The gameplay feels very genuine and solid, you'll never curse the game for slip-ups, as it's quite informative about how much AP an action or moving will work. Although knowing if something will still be blocking your shot can be somewhat confusing. The feeling of moving inside of an alien ship will fill you with as much dread as it used to. The only issue that ever came up was spotting enemies and still not seeing them in game.I was a bit skeptical about the price as I suppose I've been spoiled by steam, but this game is definitely worth it as of now. Although some of the art assets seem a bit out of place and a bit to cartoon like, the art inside the turn based is smooth and polished enough to recognize what's happening. And notice some very nice cosmetics, particularly the exterior of  the alien ships.In terms of soundtrack, you'll find it quite suspensful which is always a pleasure on games like this. The sound effects are crisp, and hearing an alien scream as you shoot across the map will give you a little fist pump moment.Honestly pick this one up and support the devs. Have fun with it and know this is one of the best successors to those old games you loved.I'd give it a 9/10, my only qualms are some of the art assets, and a few technical issues. Beyond that it's been a great game!

												Xenonauts is a new take on the classic X-COM.  You can expect the same style of gameplay, with a few different twists on weapons, environments, etc.  As someone who has invested hundreds of hours in the original games, this game is a very well done spiritual successor.  I don't know that the game has the same replay value of the original, though the game is well worth the price of a full AAA title.  Expect 45-65 hours of gameplay to get through the campaign.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												This game feels a lot like XCOM: EU where all they did was remove the best parts of the game but this time they did it even worse. The only thing great about this game is the workshop, because the vanilla game is actually pretty bad.You see, what made you invested in the tactical part of the game was the alien loot you could grab when you finished the mission. From there you could continue your research, or if you were low on funds, sell it to foreign powers. That was the best part of the game, manufacturing weapons, and then selling them to the governments of the world. It allowed you to continue funding science projects, and recruit staff had the odds swung against you. Sometimes you couldn't get enough missions or things didn't turn out right, and a few nations stop funding your project.That was removed, and from what it seems, the political aspect as well. You aren't trying to convince the governments of the world that your project can work. You seem to just get a set amount of income each year, I don't know who funds us, or why, we just get money.Well, I can take a good challenge, tough aliens, and the great level design the game throws at me. But the most disgusting part of the game is aiming. This game takes XCOM's difficulty over the top. While yes, enemies did cheat a bit, but there were few times when they could shoot through walls. But the game's difficulty doesn't come from enemy health, uniqueness, or powers or even intelligence. No. The game's difficulty comes from your soldier's ability to aim, alone. I find it hard to be invested at all in this game, with the ability to sell loot, manufacture items, or attempting to convince the UN that the xcom project works. I find it even harder to invest myself when soldiers shoot like idiots.You can have 1 alien surrounded by four soldiers, and have ALL of them miss. You can have the odds in your favor, the perfect LOS, and miss. What? You don't think it's that bad? "It might not be that bad, I'll give it a go" Let me give an example of how BAD a soldier's aim is:There was an alien in a ship, the door destroyed by my rocket launcher. I took my heavy weapons soldier, told her to fire at the alien inside of the ship. You know what she does? SHE TURNS AROUND AND SHOOTS THE SOLDIER NEXT TO HER. SHE UNLOADS ON THIS POOR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ LIKE SHE WAS INJECTED WITH ADAMANTIUM RAGE. KILLING HIM INSTANTLY.This game has so much potential, but it's like the developers thought the only way to make aliens any kind of threat was to nerf your soldier's aim. Down to the point where they couldn't even shoot an alien that's in a square next to them. Stuff like this NEVER happened in xcom, in xcom YOU'D HIT! But you were never sure if you were going to KILL!Also, the morale in this game feels so screwed up! Your soldiers would take one hit, and then immediately go beserk? The last time I played xcom, your soldiers would only go beserk if someone DIED. In fact, beserking soldiers were actually pretty rare if you kept everyone alive. And even if I'm wrong on this, they should fix it, soldiers should not beserk or panic after getting hit once.This game is frustrating but I feel like the workshop fixes some of it's problems.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Absolutely Amazing!Faithful to the original X-com, xenonauts keeps the core gameplay mechanics and tense atmosphere that made the original so awesome. Personally, i see xenonauts to be superior over the new X-Com: ennemy unknown, because the gameplay is alot more tense, visceral and complex. But not only does it come true to the original, it even expands on some concepts, adds alot of new mechanics and gadgets such as the deeper air combat missions and increased arsenal of your soldiers. Time units are back, and so comes the class-less soldier promotion system. it is up to you to choose the exact equipment and role of the soldier, and you can come up with very individual loadout choiches perfectly fit for the individual stats of the soldiers, adding alot more depth to equipment. Like in the original xcom, there is a fog of war and aliens shoot out of the dark. if you are careless with a soldier and run around a corner without looking to your side, you will soon run into trouble.And the thing that makes a real xcom game: Absolutely hilarious/dramatic soldier deaths, situations that escalate quickly, missions that end up in absolute disasters and horror. The best moments were when a plan just did not work out, one soldier after another dies, and suddenly it becomes all about saving the remaining soldiers from their certain death.The music adds to the atmosphere, and so does the fantastic art direction. I absolutely love the minimalistic, but effective graphical design, and the grim soldier portraits really add alot to the entire scenario. Occasionally there were some minor bugs which i hope will get fixed someday, and the only thing that annoyed me was the fact that there was no option to change the camera angle, as it would have made navigating trough corridors and detecting the location of grenades on the floor alot easier. Additionally the vertical view of the soldiers seems to be a bit weird, because walls do not seem to obscure the vision of soldiers on upper floors very effectively.All in all a very well rounded, challenging and absolutely awesome experience, and for anyone interested in an xcom game, i can safely declare xenonauts as the new gold standard for this genre.

Posted: July 11, 2016
												I'ts great...  But Another game where the aliens NEVER miss but you will fire shot after shot after shot after shot and every time they will miss.  It's just not fun to play.  I'm 1 and a half hours into this.  And my soldiers HAVE NOT landed more than a single, solitary, hit on the enemy.  I have had to keep reloading and trying again.  I think this is what people call "hard core".  Yeah - I haven't even managed yet to get all my troops off the back of the helicopter.  It's like that bit in Saving Private Ryan, at the beginning where they are trying to get off the life boat things, except the American's can't hit a thing and they have machine guns, and the germans have a pistol and every shot they fire kills a GI.All of the XCom games have sort of done this and I've always thought it sucked.  The worst were the games in the UFO trilogy.  I imagine that this game NEEDS you to have a maxed out Stat squad to stand a chance later on in the game?  So you simply CAN NOT tollerate taking a casualty?  Is it another of those?  Because if you have to replace someone with a Private later on and they come out like this.....The game has been a hugely dissapointing and not-really-fun waste of an hour and a half so far.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												This homage/ripoff of the original 1994 version of X-COM is generally updated and improved, but is actually more clunky and awkward by the standards of its time than the now old-enough-to-drink original game. There's no tutorial (and the game DESPERATELY needs one), you can't rotate the camera in combat, preparing your squad for combat is needlessly split across three different areas of the base, soldiers are MORE difficult to tell apart in combat than the original game because every race and gender has the exact same sprite (except for the weapon it carries).There's just NOT enough effort here to make things clear. In air combat YOUR planes show how much HEALTH they have left, but alien ships show the reverse - how much DAMAGE they have taken (remember that bit in the Bruno movie about the importance of consistency?). You can only see your weapons' stats at base (and only in a particular place at base - can't examine the weapon your soldier is actually holding, no sir, we don't like that kind of basic UI consistency around these parts, Yankee!). In combat, you don't even get to see how many Time Units you need to reload a gun - the reload button just beeps at you if you don't have enough. And don't get me started about the horrible system for reserving Time Units to shoot your gun, which doesn't reserve the Time Units you need to be able to actually turn towards the target so you can shoot it (would anyone really object if they just let you turn for free when you attack, like in the Rebelstar game on Gameboy?!)Oh, and the art and sound are just nowhere as good as the original X-COM. X-COM's blurry VGA graphics didn't age well, but at least all the aliens looked scary instead of goofy (well, maybe not those dumb Floaters or that Jello alien) and you could clearly tell which room in the base was which - you can't say that about Xenonauts. And a chill still goes up my spine whenever I hear that blaster bomb sound effect used on TV for something else.You can make a strong argument that X-COM 2012 lost some of the original's charm with "gamey" elements and being dumbed down, but it also had some clear improvements that Xenonauts is sorely lacking. Despite 2012's many terrible design choices, it's still clearly the true sequel to X-COM.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												It's great to finally see a game that lives up to the x-com legacy. It tries its own thing here and there and most of the time it manages to improve on the concept. It is not perfect, but it is a damn well realized vision and re-imagining of the original X-Com formula. If you enjoy strategy games in general, or turn-based squad combat in particular, it's a no-brainer. Buy it. Will not disappoint.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												This game was not made in a vacuum. If it were not for XCOM: UFO Defense, I doubt this game would have been made. That being said, it is more than fair to strictly compare Xenonauts to XCOM:UD and the latest, much more streamlined, XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Given the choice between XCOM:EU and this, I would choose the former. The over-simplification of XCOM that Xenonauts sought to address is no longer a concern once The Long War mod is installed. Xenonauts' incredibly plain graphics and visual design are something I just cannot get past. Everything about it is pure blandness. XCOM has unique visuals, and most importantly, small graphic nuances during the tactical combat that makes it feel like a thrilling shootout. Xenonauts on the other hand is a VERY by the numbers turn-based tactical game.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												I dont want to be too harsh, as I kind of enjoy the game. Problems are front and center though. Like aliens having amazing accuracy and your soldiers dying quite often. Its not that the loss is unbearable, I like that, its really just a balance issue. The combat is way off. Its best to just have a random guy you didnt name, push up with a shield. Then all the other characters use sniper/rifle, and a machine gunner. This circumvents the crazy high enemy accuracy/damage. It makes the combat dull and even without that element, the combat is dull enough since its really a very standard turn based combat system. The building of your base is clunky, after awhile you figure out what does what (most of it), and why you need it. But building is expensive and income is limited. Early on you can only wait to loot UFOs you shoot down. Thing about that though, is on my first game I had the game is max fast forward and waited a literal 8 minutes before a UFO triggered my radar. Bad placement, I thought... Worst of all, I couldnt catch the UFO. I waited another 3 minutes in max speed, until I got my first UFO. Then inbetween them, they were so scarce. My 3rd game was much better, still more rare then I liked, but I got about 11 of them, out of maybe 18, shot down and secured. The research and mechanic shop are nice, the game does have a good feel to it, but overall the problems with it bog it down from being overly exciting or absurd fun. I got it on humble bundle for like 2$, at that price I absolutely recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												This is not the improved x-com for which you were looking. It feels unfinished and in time modders may fill the gap but its painful and repetitive in a way that the original was not. The start of the game is well tuned and feels like the original and you don't notice how the AI reacts to your approach often increasing in aggressive level (which in gameplay terms equivalent to knowing you where you square are). However, the gameplay barely advances as the game progresses; at least on veteran alien scales faster than your weapons and there is no psi combat. This just means later missions are just slower and longer than at the start. The tech tree has the same feeling, repeated upgrades but without any excitement or dynamic change to you as the player. In addition without psi combat of your own alien psi is just another random frustrating element to add to the handful of aliens with three times the health of your toughest troops you will find camping in the final room of each downed alien battleshipI am amazed after my first few hours to say that the latest xcom reboot that i felt i barely made through the campaign without being bored probably has more replayability.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												It could've been great game, if combat, essential part of it, wasn't partially broken. I.e. if you cover one door with three soldiers, pointing all effing guns in that door, it should be obvious that when alien opens that door, he gets a hail of hot lead. Well, in this game, enemy acts first, usually opening the door, yawning and throwing a grenade in the midst of you soldiers doing nothing like some band of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. So, any reasonable tactics are out of picture, you can only press tactics that game allows, not much of it though. And this is jus one of the issues, there are many more little annoyances, that made me drop this game. If devs wouldn't screw such small things, that'd be game I'd put hundred of hours in. XCOM is way ahead.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Although I enjoy playing the game, it definitely has really clumsy and illogical mechanics to it. The game has great artwork, and the actual strategy and gameplay is solid enough for me to want to play it for a few hours at a time (which is rare), but there are things in the game that make it hard for me to recommend it.For example, corners turn out to provide 0 cover and there is no clearly defined cover system. This means that a guy crouched in a doorway with a riot shield is actually completely exposed from 45 degree angles. And the game is full of things like this. Where did you toss that grenade? At the alien? Or is it at your feet? You'll find out soon..The game is full of small bugs, poor design, and crashes every once in a while.The menu system is also extremely clunky, and could've been much better. A huge amount of the game is spend managing through the menu system that is simply painful to use, especially for the outfitting of soldiers.And soldiers are completely depersonalized except for a portrait and their origins. No matter what backround or gender a soldier comes from, they will appear on the map as a faceless white guy. There is no dialog or anything.. just feels like a missed opportunity.I love the game for the strategy and the cold war art style, but I just can't recommend it to anyone who isn't a hardcore strategy fan

number of helpful: 67 of 139 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Xenonauts is quite ok game honestly, but do not expect too much. It is slightly modernized X-COM and that's all.Graphics is indie-good. Transition to Cold War times is a nice move and ufo-generated events (abductions, crop circles etc.) adds a lot to the game creepy atmosphere. The story... well, I can't tell much about it yet, but it can turn out to be good.Otherwise this remake of X-COM is extemely close to original, even in its awful, really awful interface and slow uneventful combat system. Seriously: Time Units suck, especially when interface doesn't help you much to predict whether you have enough of them to complete your plan. Soldiers can't look behind a corner! They need to WALK behind a corner, then TURN - take a REACTION shot from an enemy - then maybe SHOOT, then WALK back. WTF. Cover system is very obscure. You cannot tell at first glance how much protection a cover offers and where you should place your soldier to use it effectively.New air combat is unnecessarily hardcore though it can have an appeal of its own. I struggled to fight against light scouts losing a fighter after a fighter, while autocombat offered me a 100% victory. It's not impossible to master, but well, it's hardcore. I warned you.Back to ground missions. Maps are extremely similar to each other. I found myself playing on the same map three times in a row, only differences being my starting place and UFO type!Xenonauts could be a much better game if they dared to shred some X-COM's obsolete features like TU's and interface micromanagement, but well, we have Firaxis XCOM with Long War mod for that.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												The game is buggy to all hell, and crashes constantly. Often not randomly. The keyboard binds do not save, and the interface is.. sticky and unpolished.Between losing support, the insane maintenance cost of multiple bases, staff, vehicles and production costs,the game difficulty curve never changes, and there is nothing you can do get ahead of it. Your troops never even get as good as the aliens troops, they are ALWAYS better, faster, more accurate.The aliens are ALL snipers (even the blind ones). They can shoot through glass, over obstacles and kill your troops in one hit easily on normal. Whereas my troops will sometimes miss a 3 yard shot with an 85% chance to hit, 4 times in a row. Or a heavy weapons soldier with a 25% chance to hit will miss all 10 bullets with his\her burst. Even with 8 Colonels for a fire team my troops cant help but shoot each other and miss 95% accurate shots way more often then they should. Additionally, shots are % based on your total time units, so your troops NEVER get to fire more shots per round, just move further.The reaction fire system makes it almost impossible to kill any aliens without getting shot yourself by the alien who's turn it ISN'T, because all the aliens seem to have AMAZING reaction times.2 Months into the game you need 4 bases and 20 fighter craft to deal with the entire worlds ufo problems and you will only have money 1\5 of that. Ufo invasions come in literal swarms so your ships sit and wait or are outnumbered 3 to 1.Scientists and engineers can NOT be moved from base to base, they must be fired and re-hired.(What year is it and how many turn based strategies have there been?)Tech options (research trees) are mundane and boring. Its the same old Balistic-Laser-Plasma, blah, blah, blah. Translation: more damage, better accuracy, different sound effects. Nothing interesting like a toxi-gun, or other biologic warfare. Even the bullets from the shotgun look like sniper and assault rifle bullets. Same with laser and plasma.All in all. The game is glitchy, my soldiers would rather shoot themselves, and it's a save\load-fest even on normal, the load times on the larger ship missions are un-godly long..oh and no quick save\load option.X-Com Apoc is STILL the best turn-based strategy. It was beyond stable, ran like water off a hydrophobic surface, good mission time vs geo-scape time balance (didn't spend 98% of your time in missions), well balanced difficulty curve (troops got dope), with interesting tech options.The soundtrack on Child of Light would get a better score than this game.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I got this game while to hold me over until xcom 2 came out and was quite hyped for it after some of the gameplay I had seen. The logistical aspect of the game, managing your bases , building facilities and hiring more staff is awesome. and has even more scope then xcom eu. The abilitiy to build and field TANKS was one of big things I was looking forward to in this game and I was not disapointed.I never played any of the original xcom games so I found the combat a little hard to grasp, and it took me awhile to figure out how turn units work, but after I got past the learning curve it wasn't bad at all.The artwork is top notch and all the lore behind research projects is well worth the read.You're probablly wondering why I'm giving this a negative review after hearing how great I think the game is, but the last is also the most important.The game feels dead.......When I go on a mission and deploy my troops there's no life, A simple idle animation would suffice so people don't look like cardboard props standing in a field. There's no discernable ambiance and while this may not sound very important, it is. The game might actually be very entertaining but after a few minutes it simply gets to dry to play.I hold high hopes for the next game because with just a little more work this game could easily be better than the current xcom.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												I waited on this game for close to what... a year now? At first I was unsure if it was worth the money, and people's complaints about LoS and other annoyances held me at bay even more. Today, finally, FINALLY a discount worth getting the game at. I love it more than the new X-Com. Not only do I already enjoy it's systems just a few hours in, but besides the stray trick-shotting alien, the game runs perfectly and feels fair. The time period is spot on, the music is spot on, and the atmosphere gets so tense that I have jumped twice playing so far. Top this with the time units, allowing you to pop out of cover and fire, the great LoS(the ability to face your soldiers and actual vision arcs)/cover (the abiltiy to crouch, and intervening objects actually having an effect on accuracy) systems and you have a tactical game that is better than most on the market. I've dumped copious amounts of money to my regret into games that are too slow or too shallow, where the atmpshere it too light for the game or the game too light for the atmosphere. Xenonauts does not stand in the ranks of those games. If you played the new X-Com, throw it away and come learn how to run an actual defense network. Buy it. I give you my word you wont regret it. The truth is out there.

number of helpful: 20 of 45 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												XENONAUTS FANBOIS BEWARE : THE FOLLOWING WILL BE A HARSH COMPARISON TO THE CLASSIC XCOM (1994 - 1995), DO NOT READ THIS REVIEW IF YOUR WELLBEING DEPENDS ON CONSTANT GLORIFICATION OF THIS GAME OR IF YOU GET UPSET EASILY : (scroll down if you want to read about reality, please)1) in parts buggy2) bad, miniscule research3) interesting aircraft-recovery, losing a craft costs nothing but WILL cost time (usually 72 hours)4) difficulty-progression is worse / more steep than in XCOM (yes, the real, classic ones) - basically you have 2 years  ... which is far from good and isnt any fun --- unlike XCOM in which the player has at least a decent amount of time before♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan5) available money seems adequate at first - but if you dont want to lose after 2 years you will need to invest EVERYTHING and fear every loss because that can (and will) end the game. Thats XCOM on high difficulty, in this game its medium. Thats sad. (i dont remember the exact difficulty-names, sorry)6) research doesnt make much sense - the results are well explained but its senseless to gain knowledge about ARMOR during PLASMA RIFLE reseach, for example - that should've been available after "alien alloys" .... and its only a small example7) air combat is a bit more fun than in XCOM - but its also a bit harder8) air-retreat has a big bug : the match ends only once the UFO (!) has left the screen, even if your fighter has already left9) ground combat is ... not bad, it basically looks like XCOM with high resolution but in that case i prefer a lower resolution - either polish the classic combat in ways which make it better or keep it like it is .... there is no in-between, everything else looks pretty cheap to be honest and thats exactly what this game is -- even the dying-animations (if one could call em that) are cheap and consist of .... one (?) single step - in XCOM it was at least 2-3 per alien.10) Music is good but the soundeffects are pretty bad - most sounds are missing or replaced by very bad ones11) It has no XCOM-like feeling, the ground combat does not instill fear, there is zero tense anywhere and  it looks like ... something boring.12) ground combat-view is not rotatable. Yes. One of the most important features in tactical, turn-based games is missing. XCOM had it. Because its necessary.13) the world map looks bad - even XCOM had a (much) better one, even in 3Dconclusion : its worse than the classics in some ways. The few additives make it worthwile for a few hours but thats it ... if you want a new (and ACTUAL) XCOM-follower this is not your game, its basically a bad version of what should've been released from the original XCOM-developers a few years after the last of the (original) series ... not bad but also not really good.

												This is an amazing game by an indie developer, well worth purchasing if you enjoy strategy or xcom or even the new x-comPresuming you know the genre alreadyPro'sYou can build more than one baseYou can build bases anwhere you like(on land) and it matters where geographically, not just 'base in xxxx country' you can protect multiple counteries with a single well positioned baseYou can build individual buildings in your bases any way you like(it matters if/when a base is attacked)Nations care wether you protect their airspaceYou can recruit soldiers and make them ANY class you like and equip them in many different ways(ie, carry a sniper rifle and  a rocket launcher if you like, weight matters of course)You can send your fighters on patrol even if you don't have radar range in a spot (get lucky!) or respond to civilian reports just outside your radar coverageMULTIPLE DROPSHIPSManufacture gearScientists and Engineers require space to live/work Beautiful music and very nice art designThere is more than 1 ufo at a time, at times.ConsCrashed once in about 20 hours of play I wish I could customize my soldiers color to more easily differentiate them(ie, know without clicking/looking at what they are carrying)You will play more than you should. . . . . . .PLEASE DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND BUY!!!!!Add me if you have any questions :)

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Certainly an interesting experience, and certainly not the worst in terms of value-for-money, but unless you are interested in the old XCOM I found that the mechanics can get quite grating towards the end of my playthrough:There is a lot of UFOs, and thus crashsites to clear, and this doesn't exectly hide the fact that there is a VERY limited number of maps - about 8, so you can expect to have to clear EACH map about 30 times if you were to manually do every mission. A related issue is that the game doesn't handle multiple levels very well - e.g. so move a soldier from the first floor to the ground floor you need to press tab once, select the soldier, then press tab about four times to cycle back to the ground floor before issuing a move order. Enemies on higher elevation can hide in spots not visible from the ground, occasionally annoyingly prolonging combat.And sadly, there is not a huge amount of gear to choose from - e.g. you end up with two choices for armour (heavy armour limiting the user to machine guns, and light armour with a jetpack that makes the character FLY nearly every time you give him a move order and also makes checking corners redundant due to 360 degree vision), which ultimately contributed to me rushing towards the end; having everyone in the annoying jetpack armour was just too damn annoying.If this review had been for the first half of the game I'd have recommended it, but with the 2nd half I don't think I can recommend the game overall UNLESS you are already into what I assume old school XCOM was like; I, at least, won't be playing it without looking very hard at mods to fix the above.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												UPDATED: With the release of version 1.51 I decided to give this game another go.Unfortunately after putting in enough time to get to the final mission I still have to give this game a thumbs down.  Much of the game has been improved, many bugs fixed but there's ultimately still some very weak or bad mechanics and a lack of balance to the game.The difficulty level even at Normal is still punishing of even the smallest of mistakes.  By the end game even with troops with almost all max'd stats using the best armor and weapons available it's not uncommon to be sniped at by monsters that are beyond view range and are very good shots, sometimes killing your soldiers in one hit or two hits.  This turns the game into a load/save fest because if you lose your well trained troops in late game it'll be very hard to train new troops with bad stats up to the level your previous troops were.There's still issues with visibility and firing angles that often don't make sense, such as cases where I'm 100% blocked from shooting an alien I can see but yet it can shoot at me.  Also missed shots are entirely too erratic, standing right behind your own tank your veteran soldiers can still fire off a shot so badly aimed it hits and severely damages your own tank.  Or trying to shoot an alien in a second story window and having the missed shot hit a stack of pallets 10 feet in front of my soldier at ground level.  I've never fired a real gun in my life but I'm confident I could get the bullet to go in the general direction of the window with minimal training.Morale also gets silly, my squad has been on dozens of missions, each member killing dozens of aliens, but still will find reason to panic or flee at times.Many UI elements are not well designed or missing information.  When you unlock new weapons that you can build in your workshop there's no tooltips in the workshop to provide details on what the stats of the weapons are.  So you end up having to blow money to build a single weapon to then look at its stats to understand if you want to bother making more.  Item weight is not listed in the tooltips either, you have to equip them and do the math to figure it out, not hard, but annoying.  It wasn't clear to me until late game that when intercepting an alien craft you can send multiple planes.  Hiring a soldier and putting them in a dropship requires going through 3 screens.It's odd that you can't build other base buildings until the command center is completed. This isn't apparent until you experience it firsthand.  So be careful - the second base you build is going to take 10 days longer than you think it will.  They should really let you plan out/execute a blueprint all at once for the entire base.  Take into account build times and existing structures automatically if you want."Run in Windowed" option only works if the resolution is less than your native desktop resolution.Other countries that you don't have coverage over seem to lose money faster than reasonable when playing at normal difficulty even after version 1.51.The entire interception portion of the game is entirely too tightly balanced and crucial to success.  I'm here for the TBS not the interception game.  Having said that, I can't stress the value in having a large air force and doing airstrikes on many of your alien crash sites.  You can't and will not want to raid them all.I ended up having to tweak the monetary values of several items in the game in order to loosen the difficulty up (on Normal) to something more reasonable to the point where the focus of the game was on the missions with your troops rather than trying to balance a checkbook.Don't get me wrong, the game isn't horrible.  However unless you're dying for a new TBS game (and I was) I'd recommend waiting till it's on sale before trying.  If you're a fan of the new XCom and are expecting more of the same look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												If you are an autismo dank memelord philosopher-warrior like myself, then this game will give you an insufferably persistent erection of the most dire intensity. This is simply one of the best strategy and tactical games I have played in years. You are leading a black ops organization that exists to defend the Earth from alien invasion, and it is multinational, receiving funding primarily from the USSR/USA but the rest of the world as well. You start at the beginning of an alien incursion into Earth, and you are charged with building base[s] from which to base interceptors, infantry strike teams and their helo transports, radar, SAM sites, research laboratories, workshops to build dank new memes for your infantry and pilots, medical centers, et cetera!The strategic side of the game occurs in the geoscape, where you make decisions regarding the administration and disposition/construction of your bases. You monitor world events - alien incursions will occur with the aim of terrorizing populations, and the more South Americans♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants, the less money they will allocate to fund your operations. You can increase your relations (and funding!) with regions by intercepting and destroying UFOs. By shooting down a UFO over land, you create a crash site, which you need to launch a raid on aliens and recover alien technology and resources. This is critical. The strategic side of this game is very engrossing.On the tactical and RPG side of the game, you scout, hire, and deploy infantry in a variety of roles, with a variety of equipment, on a variety of missions including raids/assaults and base defense. Your troops come from all over, with pertinent information (aside from their ability statistics) being age, nationality, prior unit, and combat experience. I've had an American paratrooper with combat experience in Vietnam, Soviet Spetsnaz GRU member with experience in Ethiopia, Soviet Spetsnaz with Afghan experience, Norwegian FSK, British Paras and Royal Marines, Italian Bersaglieri, et cetera... autismo dreamscapes! DANK #swagover9000Combat itself is very well thought-out and challenging. You never know what sort of enemy you will be facing, and caution is a good idea while moving out from your infil point. Assaulting a crash site is always messy, and a genuine challenge.One point of contention - I'm a Marine, and as such it pisses me the ♥♥♥♥ off to see virtually 50% of troops in the game be females. There has never been a female SEAL and never will be - why the ♥♥♥♥ am I see female Alfa, SEAL, Royal Marines, etc.? Stupid SJW ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, very offensive.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												The game is, I suppose, "fun" if you're interested in nothing but a strait rehash of the original XCOM series. And by that I mean if you're a fan of fustration and like having your butt handed to you on a platter on a consistent basis. I played through, all the way, on 'normal' mode (which is actually easier than what it's supposed to be played on, which is veteran) and the sheer unfairness of it all was mind boggling.Grunts that would have something like a 17% chance to hit at point blank range, the absolute worst RNG ever (consistent misses, also at point blank range, with shotguns when you've got like a 90% chance of hitting). Aliens that can see across the screen when you *can't*, absolutely insane maintenance costs that basically mean that if you don't optimize your initial base you'll basically never be able to make another base. Which is a problem because you *need* at least 3 or 4 bases in total if only to get radar coverage of the whole world map. To say nothing of the extreme cost putting hangers and fighters in those locations.TLDR- Horribily unbalanced combat in favor of the aliens, horribly implemented and unbalanced economy. When it's literally impossible to make a second base because your funding is so low you can't even afford to *start construction* there is a problem. Especially since the odds are extremely good that once you hit that critical point where you aren't making enough money you'll basically stay there for the rest of the game.I recommend this game only for die hard purists of the original XCOM. In every other way however the newer XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within is a superior use of your money. That and if you're really a die hard purist of the original XCOM then you could, you know, just buy the original XCOM since it is also on Steam.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												I've played a number of X-Com games... and in fact X-Com Apocalypse is my favorite game of all time, and I really wanted to like this game.  The game artwork is sorta mediocre, but the gameplay graphics are more than adequate although not anywhere near the quality X-Com Enemy Unknown.  What is most important to me in this type of game is the gameplay, and this is where Xenonauts falls woefully short.  Let me give a couple of examples.I started the game on the default "normal" difficulty, chose my starting base, and proceded to "fast forward" towards the first enemy encounter... Seconds later, a target is spotted and I send both my aircraft out to intercept the bogey.  Once they get close to their prey, they violently circle around the target at dizzying speeds until eventually they run out of fuel and have to return to base... hmm... okay.. no problem.. I will just start over.  This happens again and again over the next 3 or 4 restarts (from scratch choosing a different start location each time).. Apparently they didn't play test this part, or apparently I was very unlucky about ship positioning.Okay... Finally I get a non-spin cycle encounter, and I heroically down the bogey with barely a scratch... Time to send in the troops !   My troop ship lands and my 8 ground agents are ready to kick some alien butt !   I deploy my troops from the landing craft in pairs, being sure to reserve some Time Units for a shot or two in case aliens are close.  From past experience, I also make sure to "kneel" and take advantage of cover whenever possible.  My last troops out of the ship are Joe & Bob... and I deploy them kneeling side by side behind a nearby fallen tree trunk and I End My Turn.  The hunt is on !  Seconds later during the Enemy Movement phase, I strike it rich !... My planning has paid off !   An unwary alien has appeared direectly in front of my two would-be heros, and Bob carefullly lines up a shot with his Sniper Rifle using his extra Time Units that he saved.... HEAD SHOT !... Not the Alien... but Joe crouching 90 degrees off to his right one square away  :(Twice I removed the game from my hard drive, and twice I reloaded it in hopes that it was a quirk experience... But these experiences happened each time.   I sincerely hope that the developers/programmers work to correct these problems, and I hope I have the opportunity once again to try to play this game, but as for now, it will be removed again, and I cannot recommend it to anyone.
