content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												I don't understand the positive reviews because this game is not very polished or playable. The level of polish is from a game I would have expected 20 years ago. It doesn't have the same playability as the original XCom and shouldn't be compared to it.1. The in-game help does a poor job. Why does it say I don't have enough hangar slots for a new fighter when I have a free hangar? This and a bunch of other questions send me to google searches 10 minutes into the game.2. Why is it when I buy new solders they don't show up in my ship list?3. Why it is when one research completes it doesn't automatically start a new research on my queue, instead of requiring me to manually assign scientists?4. It's extremely cumbersome to reserve action points. I have to click or make a hotkey to reserve a certain amount, but this doesn't account for kneeling or soldier rotation.5. Melee attacks don't work, clicking the button just uses action points and does nothing.6. How many action points do I need for grenades? No way to tell that doesn't take a lot of clicks.7. How does cover work?8. How does overwatch work?9. Things which should be simple take many clicks - healing myself, throwing grenades, assigning soldier gear.There is no in-game narrative. Unlike XCom which has animations and voice acting to flesh out the feel of what is going on, you are just dumped into a bunch of spreadsheets and left to figure things out.The only real positive to the game is the 2D art, which is generally well done.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Be careful what you wish for. Xenonauts is a detailed re-invention of PC classic X-Com, which was difficult in the masochistic way gamers seem to love these days.Xenonauts also dispenses with tutorials about core game functions and mechanics. It's a complex game, and unforgiving of the slightest mistake. If that sounds appealing to you, dig in. Personally, I found it similar to those "Tough Mudder" "fun" runs. I get why some people enjoy it, but I think it's ridiculous.As a hardcore fan of the original X-com, and a fan of Firaxis' remake, I find Xenonauts tough to enjoy. Maybe I'm spoiled with "fun" gameplay, intuitive controls, and being able to play a game without reading a Wiki for hours first. But having a starting soldier equipped with "default" gear he lacked sufficient Time Units to fire, one of my jets shot down on the first UFO, and my first squad fully wiped on 3 starting playthroughs didn't make me say "wow, this is great". It made me want to do just about anything else.

number of helpful: 6 of 18 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												TLDR: Game is too repetitive, slow and has very bad UX, further exacerbating the slowness.I've completed Xenonauts on veteran today. And Xenonauts is NOT a good game. The user experience is horrible. ***Mild spoilers ahead***2 main points to illustrate, strategically and tactically:1)Strategically, this game pointlessly drags on for many, many hours more than necessary because the UFOs that contain necessary tech just simply DO NOT arrive until VERY LONG time into the game. Case in point: First Battleship for me? UFO-199... You have to go through like 100+ tactical mission drudgery just to advance the game... And you sort of HAVE TO play the tactical part because Airstrike doesn't give enough resources. Then, even when you have some Marauders (but not a lot yet), you still have to play each air combat out, and it's exactly the same, you patiently click and wait, click and wait, until you are tailing UFO for comfortable Cannon takedown to avoid taking damage... And you will have to play 10s of air battles, which gameplay you solved 10+ hours ago, just to farm enough money to afford 10+ Marauders so you can autoresolve.2)Tactically the game is also really bad. The maps are too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ large and Industrial map is the biggest nightmare of them all - you will have to advance at a REALLY SLOW pace, or else you will get killed. That is not difficulty, that is just boring. And all 90% of deaths I had was because I got so bored of advancing a few tiles a turn I just rush in with all TUs spent. Late game things get even more messed up - Once you got Sentinel Armor, you cannot simply order a soldier to move to a point, and then do it with the next one - The camera will FORCEFULLY center on a soldier who's flying MULTIPLE times and will break your control of someone in a Predator armor because your previous soldier is flying at a DIFFERENT ALTITUDE LEVEL... And thus you are forced to watch EACH of 12 soldiers SLOWLY move one by one to the target point. The same bull$hit happens on UFOs with multiple levels.I think the developers didn't play this game themselves. I do not know how they could subject anyone to this mindless boring repetitive piece of krap.What's the difference between old school UFOD and this?1)Turns resolve momentarily. In Xenonauts they take 5-15 seconds on I5-3570K. The simple AI logic doesn't warrant this amount of computation.2)The animation was instantaneous. Courtesy of DOSBox speedup, but still. In Xenonauts. you have to watch people fly for like 7-10 seconds each in Sentinel armor for NO good reason.3)The UFOD does not swarm you with pointless spam of UFOs. Maybe it should have, but you should NOT have to capture EACH of them in order to barely have enough money for anything. I've had 10 colonels by mission 30-35. Then what? Nothing - you still play 100 more combats with them, with barely any progress at all once TUs and Accuracy are maxed out.4)Game pace in UFOD is much better, you do not have to trudge through 50+ UFOs to advance to next tech level.5)With late game tech you can own small UFOs no problem. Not true in Xenonauts. Due to best armor in the game being unable to stop the very wild 50-150% damage fluctuation, you still have to be wary of a lucky burst from a simple Caesan.6)UFOD had Psi. Xenonauts? Only aliens do.Would I play this game again? Hell no. Too much time wasted NOT playing or making decisions, but watching unit animation, and waiting turns.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												DEVELOPER'S REVIEWHi. I'm the developer of this game, and I will provide an honest, accurate and totally fabricated review for XENONAUTS.First of all, we needed to find the most suitable engine for re-making X-COM. The choice was this browser game engine I found the other day. It was no longer supported, but hey---making another X-COM shouldn't be that hard, yes? So I picked it up.We ended up struggling five years to make this engine to fully address our needs. It still can't. I blame the engine. I could have asked somebody who understands game development, but I didn't. One would say I could Google it once, but I didn't do that either. Sorry that your game can not run properly. I know my apology makes it up for it, so don't thank me.While we were designing the game, we strictly followed the X-COM features. But we didn't implement random map generation, Psi-Combat, aliens being affected by morale, alien path finding, reasonable difficulty scaling, destruction, inventory management, and also any AI which is acceptable by the standards in 1994. But I think XENONAUTS is still VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY accurate and faithful to its roots.The reason why these features listed above didn't make it to the full game is, simply we're not that good at programming. Personally it took me a month to understand the necessity of loops. Our top programmer at the other hand, just figured out how to solve 8 Queens on a Board problem. Other programmers knew how to write code, but they don't know how to read code. I suspect it's because they don't write reusable and documented code, but that's just my insight. I might be wrong.On the visual side of things, we needed talented but cheap artists. It never occurred to me that these don't usually match, especially if it is marketed. So I picked up some people from DeviantArt. Overall, the game looks OK but character portraits really rule IMO.Then we had a painful period of designing the game elements. With all the lacking features that made X-COM great, we decided that the aliens should see the location of all the Xeno operatives. Also which direction they're facing so Xeno trapping the aliens is almost never possible. While we posted on forums that, random map generation and dynamic AI pathfinding is surely not possible, we were somehow incredibly skilled at keeping aliens out of Xenonaut FOV. There came the magic stroke: we made the alien FOV greater than the Human FOV. Because it makes sense and definitely not to force difficulty on players.As aliens seeing the location of human operatives are a settled and a realist fact, an inseperatable reality of extraterrestial combat at this point, we also decided to make aliens act as defensive as possible. We made the cover system work for aliens, only at times the game would feel like it. And the obstacle angles generally favor the aliens, because it's also the fight against the computer. It can process and evaluate millions of conditions in a second. In a second gentlemen, millions.In the end we finished with an X-COM remake, presented to you, made as faithful as possible. I look back at this point and I see, that I've made some mistakes but they are not as many as any game developer out there. The players on Steam are already used to unfinished, unplayable, badly programmed, unpolished, buggy, extremely slow at saving / loading and lacking games. In fact, there are already people out there who fixe our game by themselves. It'd be foolish to not use their efforts. So, here's XENONAUTS; an X-COM remake that doesn't dumb it down as Firaxis' X-COM reboot does. Have I told you that it helped us a lot that they chose to make a "crappy X-COM reboot"? It really made up for our incompetence so we could trick you classic X-COM gamers to buy this game.Thank you, XENONAUTS Dev.P.S.: Mac and Linux ports don't work. Sorry about that.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I really wanted to enjoy this game.  But I didn't.It's hard to quantify exactly what sucked the fun out of the game for me, I think it's a combination of elements.Graphics:  awesome .. if it were the late 90s and the game were a direct sequel to UFO: Enemy Unknown.  But it isn't.  I just found the graphics - whether units, localities, base drawings .. to be very underwhelming.  I know they were aiming for "retro charm" possibly because they couldnt afford/achieve "acceptable for modern gaming".  (I do like some retro-charm games, like FTL .. but I guess I suffer the graphics because I enjoy the gameplay.Gameplay:  where to start .. ?   I found the AI to be pretty simple -- the action point system quite painful, especially managing large numbers of units -- the fog of war to be quite annoying (I dont mind fog of war in general, but in this game it's just an ugly mechanic and in many ways not intuitive .. like not seeing over a hedge) -- on a good note, the progression of units felt OK -- the strategic map and base building was OK but .. dunno, it didn't feel to me like a gripping financial sim, which was one of the appeals of the original.Research tree, all the incidental stuff - dunno .. just felt "been there, bought the t-shirt, don't need to go back".I had no particular expectation of the game .. which is usually a good thing because you're not set up for disappointment .. and yet somehow I came away disappointed anyway.Maybe it's just because the formula hasn't aged well.  I enjoyed the original games, played up to Xcom: Apocalypse (which I also enjoyed despite being outraged and culture shocked by the fact that they confined it to a city).  But yeah .. in my opinion Xenonauts is a pretty bland game .. maybe a 6/10 ..My advice is to kick the tyres and look at some videos before deciding to pick it up.

number of helpful: 4 of 15 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Abysmal and painful to play.This really is a classic example of the boring retro for the sake of retro trend that is the equivalent of hipster music fans insisting that anything after a band's first demo is crap. The same people who obsess over this will be the same ones who whine about the brilliant Xcom enemy unknown game for being "cinematic". Such heresy, how dare modern technology actually make games fun to play and enhance the atmospherics and visuals while also giving it a gameplay system that actually works. The negative reviews here hit on some key issues, the combat is unbearable, illogical and random, crouch makes no sense, visibility is a mess as well, can be a few tiles away from an enemy and they'll just disappear from view, you can't use anything properly for cover or aim over or around anything, but hey, I guess realism and better gameplay don't matter, that's "too cinematic" and we must rigidly cling to the outdated systems of early 90s video games. Also even on easy the game is not so much hard as plain awkward as your soldiers can't shoot for s**t and half the time end up firing at each other instead, the interface in general is as awkward and inaccessible as the old games if not worse and unlike modern games that actually have these things called tutorials and learning curves it just expects you to figure all of this out at the start. The graphic style leaves a lot to be desired, whereas the likes of shadowrun, wasteland 2 and xcom have done a fantastic job of updating the visuals while remaining faithful to the classic and newly revived isometric format, Xenonauts has this silly cartoonish style that I really can't take to. Also the audio mix seems a bit off, can barely hear the ambient music, but the only settings in the game you can alter at all are controls....Just the whole combat system is so outdated and tedious to play, as soon as someone's wounded they can't do anything, does the game tell you what to do to heal them? Of course not, but I guess you can only know how to play this game if you grew up with 90s xcom games. I guess this is something for rigidly conservative gamers incapable of trying out anything made past 1995, but modern turn based games do the whole isometric sci fi tactics much, much better. Trying this overhyped disappointment just makes me more impatient for a follow-up to the Xcom Enemy Unknown and Enemy WIthin games.This modern trend of just shamelessly regurgitating retro games and outright refusing to take on board what games since then have achieved and moved forward with is just very tedious and pretentious. I am all for a degree of nostalgia and for reviving the classic isometric style but it's been shown in shadowrun and enemy unknown that you can take the best of both worlds without completely straying from the style of the classics. They're still old school at heart.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												So far, I'm rather disappointed.  While I was hoping for XCOM UFO Defense expanded and prefected, what I got was a rather dumbed-down version with some Facebook-esque artwork.  What's worse is that upon researching the game, I learned that there were several great features cut during early access and dumbed down, with developers being extremely hostile towards anyone who thought otherwise.Let's start off with the good: First of all, it's more XCOM.  No, not Firaxis' streamlined and modfiied reboot, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but the classic XCOM: UFO Defense and Terror from the Deep.  It's got a wider scope than the reboot, more micromanagement, and places equal emphasis on your planning as it did combat, unlike the more combat-focused reboot.  Regardless of your opinion on Firaxis' attempt to reboot the franchise (which I absolutely loved), this game is a completely different experience.Air Combat has been revamped, and feels like a game mechanic rather than a short prayer to the AI Director that has screwed you over so many times in your Warframe loot tables and L4D2 sessions.  It's one of the few changes I genuinely enjoyed, a fully realized version of the air combat in which you operate your ships in real-time and attempt to outmaneuver the alien contact.Variety of weapons.  XCOM classic had launchers, Assault Rifles, and pistols, Xenonauts added Snipers, LMGs, and Shotguns.New feature: Airstrikes.  They cost $15,000 and you miss out on loot, but if you simply don't have the resources to respond, you may have to take the loss to control damage.  It's a great addition, and one of the ways this game's best points is interception.  Now, let's go ahead and address the neutrals.External launcher.  I count this as a negative, but it's simply something I really can't take too harshly.Civilians are almost ALWAYS present.  I have mixed opinions on this, as while it gives the missions a bit more tension, it turns civilians into a regular instance of combat.  In XCOM, The announcement of a terror mission genuinely scared you, as it put your entire monthly rating on the line.  It threw off your usual strategies, and it forced you to take risks you would have never done before... now, civilians are just a "oh well, let's go through plan D."You're no longer protecting a planet, you're looking at a map.  Whatever, I think I'm done nitpicking for now.As much as I love some of the changes present, the rest of the game completely kills the praise I could have had for the game.  Well, let's get the pitchfork and burn this thing down:Artstyle.  It's cell-shaded and looks like it belongs in a Facebook game.  XCOM UFO Defense can pass as pixel art, and its visuals have aged fairly well.  This game already looks dated and distgusting.As I said, the mechanics are horribly dumbed down from XCOM UFO Defense, and combat isn't nearly as interesting.Somehow, they managed to make the XCOM UI block even more convoluted and unorganized.  I didn't even think it was possible, but despite the fact that XCOM was meant for resolutions ranging from 200p to 480p, it's amazing that with all the extra screenspace Xenonauts managed to do an even worse job of organizing the UI.If this were its own game, I would be willing to overlook the flaws and recommend it anyway.  However, it isn't an independent game, it's just an XCOM clone without the same kind of flair that the classic holds.  For $15 less, you can get the original and with the OpenXCom mod, it stomps all over Xenonauts.  If you really want a streamlined XCOM experience, you should just buy XCOM Enemy Unknown Complete when it goes on sale for $10, as it does often, then enable 'aiming angles' to make the RNG elements more predictable and balanced.  I'll still give this game another chance, but I'm not very optimistic.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												After enjoying XCOM Enemy Unknown (XEU) and Within, I decided to give it  a  try.  I started the game and had no clue what to do. Had to go back and read stuff. OK, lot of common elements to XEU but with a very clunky interface. Fine. So this game has an strategic level more complex than XEU. Many of the mechanics are similar to  XEU like constructing the base by expanding locations and selecting what to build. Combat is also similar turn based and using cover, changing weapons, etc. But I just have no fun with this game. Here is what I dislike. The combat in XEU is implemented much better. For example,  in XEU line of sight works is carefully implemented. In Xeno it seems they use a random factor to simulate it and it doesn't work well. For me combat was the most fun part of XEU and it is the worst part of Xeno. Xeno relies low hit rate to simulate difficulty. Chance is not a replacement for implementing strong combat elements like line of sight. XEU adds chance on top of strong combat elements, that is fun. Xeno adds chance as a replacement to implement strong game elements, that is not fun. I will stop purchasing games with low production values like Xeno. This seems implemented for the 1980's before dedicated graphic cards were implemented.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Direct ripoff of the UFO series, which would offer a lot of quality time is implemented in a nice and clear manner. However, not only bugs like an occasional bullet through wall mar this incarnation of UFO, but the gameplay is basically broken. You'll end up with a boring series of save / make a move / see if it turns out well in the enemy turn / load. Save / Load. Save / Load.... which makes a boring play. The reason to save so often is that you can ill afford losing soldiers, whose abilities will get better with time. Also if you're new to the game you have no way of knowing which research does what exactly and base management is a silly drag with limitted space. What finally killed the game for me was the Predator armour. Going into action with two heavy armour suits had shown that they're a bit better than Wolf, but they'll easily get penetrated by the aliens. Anoter note is that aliens are not much worse than your squad, so statistically your chances of making it through 100 fights with your people intact are zero unless you save and load and load and load ...I've had more fun at work than playing this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Well I was a fan of the original X-COM (since 1994) and have (I think) played all of the X-COM-likes and X-COM clones to date.  Some have been interesting, most have been fairly bad but Xenonauts is special.You could put it this way, of all the X-COM clones over the last 20 years, Xenonauts is the most faithful.  In a way it is aiming to be the "ideal" version of X-COM, like it want's to be more X-COM-ey than X-COM somehow.  It does not attempt to introduce new core mechanics, blasphemy!  No wacky moves into mixed real-time mode and definitely no newfangled 3d!  It's like the dev sat down and said something like "This game is going to be EXACTLY like X-COM exept where it is better!  Because, I don't like things that are different!".Unfortunately the result is inferior to X-COM in every possible way.  And, it comes off as being devoid of any creative inspiration.  It looks like the Chinese, knock-off t-shirt of X-COM games.Since Xenonaut's only selling point would be the graphics, to review it you have to talk about that.  The graphics in Xenonauts are a slight improvement over the 1994 X-COM game.   But, they're embarrassingly crude by today's standards.  Xenonauts released shortly after games like X-COM Enemy Unknown and The Banner Saga which have set consumer expectations for this sort of game fairly high.An effort has been made to give the Xenonaut sprites smooth (rotoscoping?) animation.  Despite this welcome improvement the visual style is... well... bland, I suppose... insipid, maybe?  This whole game honestly made me wonder why this developer bothered to publish this product.  But, I think it might have had something to do with cashing-in on X-COM's recent popularity, in what essentially amounts to stealing IP.Anyway, that aside, Xenonauts is playable but don't get your hopes up for a "dream come true" X-COM update / remake.  It borrows freely from other, better games but gives nothing back to the genre.  It would comfortably make the grade as a marketable product for steam but beyond that it is only memorable for its extreme lack of creativity.It's very, very strange to see this sort of game come from indie developers.  It's a postcard from a topsy turvy world where indie devs cannot innovate and try to compete based on graphics.

number of helpful: 4 of 16 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Aliens dont follow the rules of the game. It can say 100% blocked line of fire for you, but on the aliens turn they stay in the exact same position and kill your men. You can stay right behind a tall one square obsticle and it will say 100% blocked line of fire for you, in spite of the manual saying otherwise, and still the aliens can kill you behind that obsticle.Sometimes the "cover" system works, meaning you can stay behind a corner of a wall and shoot around it at a spotted alien by another unit. But other times you cant.UFO doors that you open on your turn stay open when its the aliens turn and they fire at you, and then closes when its your turn. If the doors are opened by the aliens on their turn, they close just the same on your turn. Spoiler: Blow the fricking door open.Losing soldiers to faulty game mechanics is not the way I want to be beaten by the AI!Downed UFOs are all the same. They never have holes blown in their sides that can use to enter the craft, you allways have to use the front door.Combat maps are decent. They are made of several smaller chunks, smaller than other X-com clones I've played, making the maps seemingly more varied. I've come across the same chunks very often, so there arent alot of them - yet. Maybe a modding community can rectify that.If you compare it to the original, which they clearly want (they even called their game X-COM one place in the manual) they have less stats than it. Xenopedia lacks info. You need to visit the soldier equipment screen to find the stats of the different weapons, and then only in a hard to activate mouseover popup. Cudos to the role system they have for the soldiers, making it very easy to switch equipment on soldiers. Is the game bad - No. Is it better than all the other clones out there - No, not really. Developers did their best. Its just so fricking unfortunate that they did the same misstakes as others did. "Fully destructive terrain!" - yea, only if you try to blow up the parts that they want you to blow up. Too bad. Its just another clone that doesnt meassure up as a successor. Disclaimer: This wall of text is without spelling errors and faulty grammar. If you see any - then the gnomes did it.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Generally a good remake of original UFO: Enemy unknown in year 1994. Would want to give the game "recommend". However, the unrealistic setting in regarding to the financing, world political, world economy setting (by comparing to another xcom title - x -com : Enemy unknown) and the excessive punishment setting which prevent me to enjoy the game. 1. The organisation is poorly financed by the world and expectation is unreasonably high. Easily get financial punishment without a proper reason. Unable to expand due to financial problem.2. Reward setting is poor. Success in high risk mission do not end up with equivalent high reward. (Destorying an alien base do not get apprasal from the local government)3. Financing setting is poor. Limited option to get additional financing. Reselling price of advance equipment is unreasonably low just like the alien technology is commonly available to the world4. With such high end technology and elite soliders on hand, the organisation can simply choose to walk away and get financial from other source (selling alien technology, equipment in black market, team with the most rich in the world) and deal with the alien threat on its own (just like some other sci-fi fiction). Therefore, the excessive punishment setting in the game is not enjoyable. Beside, if the government choose to kill itself, who care. The end of the government does not mean the end of the world, so long the organisation continue to exist. Sadlessly our real world actually telling you this in these recent years.Anyway, the main point is, as a simulator, it would not be harmful if the game include the original rule set, improved rule setting and custom rule set for player to suit their style.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game is XCOM. It ***is*** XCOM. If you own any of the XCOM games, save your money and play them instead.Don't get me wrong: there's nothing wrong with it. It's just that it's so much like XCOM that I'm surprised it's allowed to exist. There's nothing new about it except for a graphics update, and if you've played any of the latest console versions of XCOM, even that's not there. So, why am I surprised it's allowed to exist? It's just a photocopy of the XCOM. To me, this game borders on trademark/copyright infringment. It's like me opening a McDonald's restaurant and making just one change: calling the restaurant McDanold's.I've read other reviews where people have written, "This is XCOM as is was meant to be," or "This is XCOM perfected." Really? Well, I guess it was perfect before, then, because as I wrote, there's not much new about it. There are some changes: it takes place during the Cold-War, you can control your interceptor when fighting UFOS (think Zaxxon or Defender), and I guess sometimes your interceptor faces multiple enemies. However, these things are all superficial changes.Now, I have to say that I've only played the game for around three hours, so maybe there's something new that pops up at five hours, but I highly doubt it. I also have to say that I really didn't look into what this game offered before I bought it, so my feeling of getting ripped off is my own fault. But please listen to me: if you're looking for a game that might be like XCOM but better, this isn't it. This is just XCOM: Enemy Unknown. If you already own that or another XCOM game and you like it, play that when you're hungry for a fix. Don't buy this one.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Oh alright. I've finally found myself reviewing this game. There's a lot of thoughts slewing around in my head about this game. And I've finally come to a conclusion. In it's core concept it's a literal sucessor to UFO defense. For, at the time of this post, 5 times the price of the original  X-COM UFO Defense on steam. The guns are pretty unbalanced, generic and boring, the game feels odd, it doesn't feel like an advancement from the original. There are currently a lot of problems with this game. And I could go on and on about them. Most of them have to do with the gameplay. (However I should note the modder community is currently doing a lot for the game, making a lot of new weapons and whatnot to be put into the game.) There's a difference between 'Difficult but fair' and 'Difficult and stressful'. The developers have yet to figure out how to do the first one. Until the game is patched up a lot and a lot of the game hopefully fixed, I don't recommend this game to anyone. It's not so much that it's bad, but you almost might as well get the original game unless you're willing to spend $20 more for updated graphics and unbalanced gameplay.

number of helpful: 10 of 36 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												Xenonauts suffers from what many other games of this type suffer from, and that is "click to roll dice.  input not required further.  listed results not guaranteed, unless it disadvantages player".  This is probably the best game in this genre in many years, far surpassing the Xcom remakes, but is still more of a dice simulator than a game.  Actual gameplay does exist in Xenonauts, but its built in such a way that every decision is a pass/fail state.  IE, build your starting base in the wrong place, fail after an hour or two.  Build in the right place, survive for a couple hours.  Research the right techs and build the right corresponding devices, extend playtime 30 minutes to an hour.  Build anything else, end gameplay with failstate.  This will continue until the game over screen or the campaign victory screen.  Its a lot like hardcore 2d platformers in that its all about memorizing the right steps to take at the right times.  The most painful aspect to this is that you can easily survive awhile with the wrong decision, which gives you a false sense of progress, only to run into a brick wall that jolts you with "hmmm so choosing X tech over Y tech an hour ago would have trivialized this new threat/mechanic."  That is all there is to this game. Positioning of your soldiers in ground combat is nearly exactly the same.  There are 2 or 3 tactics that are nearly guaranteed to win you battles, and about a million tactics that literally wipe out your entire squad/fleet/base in a single round and end your campaign, and most succesful tactics involve exploiting some factor of the design.  Save scumming is easy in this game but really isnt that useful unless you want to avoid the dozens of hours required to get to the next pass/fail state and figure out the required move(hint: save scum for awhile to figure it out, then play a perfect campaign at whatever difficulty you want.  then uninstall. otherwise your just going to end up disapointed with the time you spent running the campaign to figure out the states). Something about the artwork and written lore however, really give this game VASTLY more atmosphere and character than the high budget cutscene and voice acting laden sexed up Xcom remakes.  That is both a compliment to Xenonauts and a slash on the Xcoms, but the fact remains there is almost nothing redeeming about this style of game. Getting attached to your soldiers is something much talked about, but neither Xcom nor xenonauts really have any personality in the characters and thus losing them is really only troubling due to losing a unit that has higher on screen dice rolls that ultimately are utterly meaningless given the inherent hit/death gameplay.  Much has also been made about the difficulty and Ironman modes, and to that i refer you to the wall of text i just wrote.If you are into it though, then Xenonauts is the best game you can buy in this genre on the market currently in my opinion.  It at least feels the most like a game and seems to be from developers that are genuinely interested in fake gameplay and interesting universes.

number of helpful: 9 of 35 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This game has two levels: the strategic geoscape, and the tactical maps.The strategic aspect of this game is spot on.  Building facilities and managing your budget are key aspects to this game.  And the most enjoyable.That being said, the tactical part of this game sucks.  It is ENTIRELY based on a poorly designed random number generator (RNG.)  The RNG determines if shots will hit or not.  Your shots frequently miss (and your soilders are ex- SPECOPs by the way,)  while shots from the aliens will pass through several solid objects, including shields and other soilders (without injuring them) and fatally strike a soilder you were retreating.  Shots will frequently miss even at point blank ranges with all weapons, especially with shotguns and sniper rifles (I mean, really, shove the gun down the xeno's throat and pull the f---ing trigger.)  Your troops seem to have failed basic training (read: boot camp.)  They will FREQUENTLY panic without even being shot at.  They will throw down their weapons and run (I once had a soilder run INTO a UFO.  (What the f--- made you think of that idea dumba$$?)  You can not sling a soilder's weapon, throw a grenade, and unsling the weapon (so its back in your soilder's hands) during the same turn.  Needless to say, this make a panic smoke grenade impossible.  It seems that some doors are incapable of being closed (really, you're in the military and you can't close certain doors?)  It seems your soilders are incapable of melee combat without a certain weapon (a stun batton.)  (So, let me get this straight, you DON't know how to slam the butt of your rifle into a xeno's face?)  I've also had issues with soilders throwing grenades at thier feet.  (I'm not even going to say anything about that.)  Finnaly, the alien's psionic abilities are completly imbalanced.  Theroretically, they are capable of mind controling a soilder they can't even see while he is still on the dropship (and possibly dropping a C4 charge with zero turns on the timer.)  Not good at all when a core mechanic of the game is permadeath.(My English teacher would be saying to start a new paragraph here, so...) Then there are bugs.  Aliens seem to be capable of seeing through walls (then running up to your assult trooper holding a shot gun and blow his (your soilder's) brains out.  Meanwhile, your three other soilders covering that door don't do a damn thing.  I've had issues with blank screens and freezing as well (and this is a very resource unintensive game runing on a gaming PC.)  I've had soilders get shot, survive, and then drop dead as soon as my turn begins.  Finnaly, in the year 2014, this game uses a launcher.  A launcher that will not launch itself with certain background programs running (i.e. firewall and anti-virus.)

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Interesting concept. On the plus side this game does offer gameplay reminiscent of the original XCom series. The abilty to research alien technology and then reverse engineer to enhance your team of elite soliders as they battle aliens in a variety of tuen based senarios is still there. Also there is the need to manage the logistics surrounding managing your resources including contsructing new equipment and costs associated with expanding  your bases facilitites. What is different is the pace of gameplay. Even on easy setting this game is very difficult, so much so that you find yourself saving and reloading again and again. The result is slowed gameplay that often feels like a real slog whereas the original titles were challenging but well paced. Other annoyances include the constant bugs that plague each release. All of my games work seamlessly with the expcetion of this title which crashes again and again. I accept this is a beta but this game is well into its software development life cycle so I'm dismayed to see so many problems still cropping up this late in the piece (the designers state they want to release this game in its completed form early this year). With the exception of die hard fanboys I can not see this title have much appeal to mainstream gamers like myself. Good effort but still not enough to dethrone the original Xcom titles.

content:

Early Access Review
								Still too buggy.   Lost my entire roster of soldiers when I reloaded my save from the previous night.It is a fairly faithful re-creation of X-COM, except for the cold-war skin they've wrapped it in, but I'm reluctantly forced to admit that Time Units are a fairly bland and overly complicated mechanic that ultimately slows down the game flow.  Games have been dumbed down quite a bit since 1994, but in some ways they have evolved as well.  What Xenonauts tries to do, it does well, but better ways to do it have been thought up since then.XCOM EU used the D&D4e rules to great effect on ground missions, and it was much less headache inducing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												What a fond drive down memory lane this game is. For those of us old enough to remember the original X-com, this game will bring back happy and deliciously frustrating memories of that wonderful classic. What the current bearers of the X-com flame have failed to deliver,  the makers of Xenonauts have. We don't need a cheesey 1950's gimmick, or a story line that no one really cares about. We just want to play turn based combat with aliens like we had in the old days. The original X-com was frustrating, easy to get into, yet difficult to master and insanely addictive, Xenonauts is all of that, and more.   This game gives the gamer hours of deep strategic thinking, but without the tedious busy work of many other strategy games. You build your bases, improve your technology, hire and fire researchers, engineers and soldier, try your best to manage your budget (which is more important than one would assume), and all of this while fighting for humanity's very survival, on interesting battlefields all over the globe.     This game is wonderful for those of us who stayed up until dawn in the 90's playing the original, and for younger or newer gamers who want to have that same experience. Take it from an old school PC gamer, if you want all of the fun of the good old DoS days, but with a bit of a graphic and processing revamp, this is it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Xenonauts does a great job of hitting that sweet spot where they've managed to significantly improve upon the original XCom games without losing the essential essence of them. They clean up and improve the UI substantially, giving you data you didn't have in the 90s like hit probabilities. They revamp and scrub the game's economy, eliminating some of the easier ways to get money, forcing you to rely much more on maintaining good relationships with world governments. They revamp the research tree, making the progression of technologies more sensible and less vulnerable to work-arounds. They tweak the combat system, adding new weapon and equipment types so that much more strategy has to go into your soldiers' layouts.Even with all these changes, this is the game I loved back in the day--or maybe better yet, it's the game I never even dreamed XCom could have been. Anyone who liked the original XCom should definitely try this game. Younger gamers who don't remember the original may find this game too challenging or not flashy enough, but strategy enthusiasts should give this game a try as well.

Early Access Review
								Revist/remake of the old school Microprose UFO: Enemy Unknown game. Its very similar to the original with a lot of the content removed(multi-format release) from the latest XCOM game returning .This game has improved strategy in the global setting over Xcom, with you needing to way up more options like; do I build another base to incease radar & aircraft range or add labs & scientists to get better equipment. Time is not on your side, funding dissapears very quickly on hard settings, especially due to unmonitored alien activity.The visuals do a decent job as does the AI (on normal & above). The maps are reasonably varied, yet do repeat slightly more than i'd like. They're about the right size & unlike the original I havent found myself hunting the map for the last camping in a loft alien for 30 mins. Theres also a nice addition in the form of being able to airstrike downed UFO's rather than sending a team in. Overall I've throughly enjoyed this so far and am happy to recommend it, if you havent played the original this is well worth your money. Do bare in mind though that the game is very unforgiving, especailly on the more challenging modes.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Play it with the money and weapons mods because it makes the game fair on your end. The money mod makes sense so I didn't feel any gamer guilt using it. If the world was under alien invasion I am pretty sure every goverment would scrap the idea of money and just use whatever resources Earth had to defend it....not charge those responsible defending for a garage and such. The weapons mods do give you a good advantage in a ways but still those aliens will one shot you, through a wall or just walk right up to your units and MURDER all of them. You will miss just about every shot and each alien takes about three to four rounds but with the weapons mods it gives you a chance. The air combat is great and hope XCOM 2 has something along the lines. Overall it is a great game, has that looming atmosphere of the unknown, great music, the art is good (especially in the alien autopsies and weapon/gear descriptions) besides the character models. They could have done a bit more because your soldiers look extremely plain and paper cut outs. The micromanagement of your bases and world events is pretty awesome too. I suggest this game if you liked XCOM games in anyway. Just use the mods, my first ten hours of this game were without them and I was so hopelessly frustrated.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												I've been following this title for ages and while I couldn't resist trying out the alpha demo about two years ago, mainly checking the looks and feels, I never really played the pre-release versions. I prefer having a complete experience, so I patiently waited for the magical 1.0.And now it finally arrived. I am not disappointed.I completed a playthrough on Normal not using Iron Man Mode in an 18 hour session, interrupted only by a short break to catch some Zs. I was pretty much hooked right from the start. The base building and overall beginning of the game is very XCOM-y. If it wasn't for the 2D geoscape you might as well be thinking you're playing the original. But there are certainly differences.Aerial Combat:The mini game for this got made over quite a bit. You can manually move your jets around the battlefield and issue basic orders like 'evasive maneuvers', 'fire missile' and 'retreat'. I found it especially fun to fight bigger UFOs. Get one Jet to distract the enemy and another to get on the bogeys tail, hammering away on his butt. If you don't like this kind of gameplay you can just let the CPU auto-calculate the outcome for you, with the approximate winning chance displayed on the encounter screen.Annoyances:- The Corsair is way too strong, making alien air superiority fighters nothing more than a nuissance.- The amount of UFOs appearing during end game can get quite the hassle. Not because they are dangerous, but because it ends in a neverending clickfest.Ground Combat:Awesome. Finally you can freely equip your soldiers again (unlike in Firaxis' XCOM, which had way too few options after my fancy). You can use a squad with different specialists or just stick to a jack-of-all-trades kind of team. I managed to work with the latter, but it was way more difficult and less fun at the same time. However I only played on normal difficulty, so I don't know how viable this is in harder modes. I'd definitely recommend going for specialized troops.Aliens behave differently. There are smarter ones and dumber ones. Overall the AI is ok, but not breath taking. Yet the suspense IS there. Playing the game in a pitch black room, sweeping the area for hostiles while trying to keep your men and the civilians alive never ceases to be great and thrilling fun.Movement and aiming hasn't changed much, but the newly included suppression system makes the combat feel way more alive. It counters reaction shots, so you can't just camp in a good position until the sun explodes. However this tactic is very often neglected by the AI. Would like to see them be more aggressive. Yet again, maybe that's the case in harder modes.Also, you can now just bomb crash sites if you don't need anything in particular from it. This will yield no XP/loot but money. Really saves you from getting dizzy doing the 100th scout UFO ground mission for just some crap loot. Good thinking there.Annoyances:- Why no quicksave/-load? The hardcore crowd will play in Iron Man Mode anyway, so why not include this simple feature? If I just didn't see the button, shame on me.- Sometimes maps repeat, I only ever had it happen twice I think, but it shouldn't happen during the same game at all.- Alien Bases are too similair. I always found the base commander in the same corner of the base (I did 5 base assaults). Can this be randomized a little more? (Why did I just write 'base' four times in one sentence?)- Why are there ALWAYS civilians? If a UFO crashes in no man's land, there shouldn't be any. Just a minor thing, but the occasional map without friendly NPCs would do for some randomization as well.Tech Talk:Uhh, well it's an indie game with a 2D engine. If you expect some fancy AAA effects and stuff you will be disappointed. But I have to admit the ingame sprites and art work in the game's encyclopedia are very good. The battlegrounds look great and especially the alien assets (and UFOs) look very nice. Sound effects are nothing too special but meaty enough. The music during ground combat is awesome though and really helps create the creepy mood. Well done!Conclusion:That pretty much sums it up. The geoscape gameplay is mostly the same as always. Research, build, expand, intercept. I wouldn't know what to drastically alter there and everything is well made, so it's fine for me.All in all I am very impressed and would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the old XCOM games or is looking to get into this kind of genre.tl;dr: 9/10 would play again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Xenonauts is a wonderful clone of the original XCOM - UFO DEFENSE and is in many ways a better experience. Xenonauts is more intuitive and pretty than its predecesor as well as creating the same feeling that you are juggling 9001 balls at once, and are constantly a few poor choices away from total collapse. All in all, the game is a great experience.Although I have not completed the game, just scratched the surface really (I've played three months in-game), I can say for certain that all of the difficulty of the original game is present. Every desicion is vital and it is imperative to really consider the best course of action at all times. If you don't, well, let's say there have been more than a few missions which resulted in complete annihilation of my squad, a terrible loss.The game is also much more faithful to the original than XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN, bringing back TU's, much larger squads, and a more complicated geoscape portion of the game. In many respects, though, it improves on the original. The OP Blaster bomb has been removed, the graphics look polished and attractive, and useful/relevant data is more easily accessed.However, I do not mean to say that the game is without faults. For new players to the series, there is hardly and tutorial to introduce them to the many facets of being an international super-secret alien defense force commander. This means the learning curve can be quite steep. Furthermore, the game has some frustrating line of sight issues. Sometimes, I will attempt to move my soldier to firing position, only to discover that the bush I was trying to shoot through might as well be a solid wall. Although over time I have been able to more successfully ascertain what I can and can't do, it has provided a great deal of frustration.All in all, the game is excellent, and in my oppinion more pleasurable to play than the original. (Although the punishing nature of the original adds a bit to the feel. Ironically by making it better it's worse?) Anyway, if you are a fan of strategy games or the original series then I would highly recommend you purchase this game immediately and begin fighting off the extraterrestrial invasion!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								What can I say about Xenonauts? Well, if you are an oldie such as I. Then you will come to appreciate old classics, like Ufo Alien defence (The old X-com), Jagged Alliance 2 and Panzer General. With the exception of Panzer General, the other two are very similar games. With their core underlying mechanics being grounded in managing a team of soldiers in accomplishing some sort off objective. How is that relevant? Well, for starters. You need to understand what this game is trying to accomplish. And that is replicating an old classic and making it more pleasing to the eye. The 'pleasing to the eye' has already been accomplished by the remake Firaxis has made. So again the question is: What does this game bring? Well it successfully manages to incorporate the core aspects that made the original Xcom so great into a neat little package that is pleasing to the eye and keeps the features rich. 'Feature Rich', that is the key here. Everyone including me loves the new remake of X-com very much, but again, if you are like me. Then you will yearn for the classics. In that case, what better then to play a pseudo remake?

Posted: June 16, 2014
												This is an extremely faithful remake of UFO: Enemy Unknown, even down to the original title's shortcomings. One of those shortcomings is quite a dated and complicated interface which feels lacking in many areas even compared to the original 1994 game. Xenonauts also doesn't bother explaining much about itself, so prepare for a high learning treshold, especially if you haven't played the classic original.But it makes up for it with some lovely (albeit tiny) graphics and atmosphere, and of course, the original tactical battles on random maps with roaming aliens that the Firaxis X-COM remake got completely wrong (although the cover system was a nice improvement that this game could have used). It's interesting to note that both X-COM and Xenonauts feel like they have line of sight issues compared to the original UFO, so prepare for some frustrating moments, in addition to those "normal" frustrating UFO moments! :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Review based on V1.01Most of what is good in this game has to do with the fact that for the most part its gameplay is copied directly from the original (1994) XCOM. XCOM is easily one of the best designed games ever, so a faithful remake can't be too bad by definition, and this one is not bad at all.Where Xenonauts tries to diverge from XCOM it does that with mixed results. For example, the alien races are quite a bit more diverse. One of the starting races is tough, has innate regeneration, but poor eyesight and is best dealt with from a distance. The starting weapons are great - the classic pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle and machine gun differ not only in stats (as in the original), but in their tactical values. Shotguns are deadly close-up, machines guns dish out tons of damage and can easily punch through obstacles, sniper rifles are amazingly accurate from a distance. Advancing the weapon tech is, unfortunately, quite boring. It is the same set of classic weapon archetypes all over again, only gradually more powerful. This is exactly the same as in the original game, but after seeing the initial diversity of ballistic weapons this was very disappointing. I had the same issue with the Firaxis XCOM - a "laser shotgun" just has to be one of the silliest sci-fi weapon concepts. The more interesting parts of the original tech tree, like the mind probe, the motion scanner, the psi technology and the blaster launcher are no longer in the game. The UFO activity seems to be much more involved, later in the game the aliens will start defending their missions with aggressive fighter wings that will bring down your dropship or fighters returning from a mission if you are not careful. The aerial terror missions are also a nice touch.On the other hand, the interception mini-game is highly repetitive, and very slow-paced - I have been using autoresolve most of the time because it gets very tedious after just a few interceptions, and the game will usually swarm you with UFOs because of how the economy works.I really didn't like the change where the engineers can no longer build items for profit - that option made a lot of sense in the original game (though was  probably too good to the point of Xenonauts' authors calling the feature an "exploit"). In Xenonauts your engineers are just wasted resources unless you need something built immediately, which you don't always do, so they have to be fired / re-hired as needed to save money.The funding provided by the nations is just about enough to run 2 bases and fund two workshops. The only source of income for further expansion are the UFO raids, which are (relatively) less profitable than in the original, and therefore have to be more frequent. There is even an option to earn about 33% of the downed UFO's worth by bombing the crash site in order to avoid losing money when the ground squad is not available. Still, the income is quite low. For instance, the cost of a new base is $1M. Medium-sized UFOs that are prevalent in the mid game are worth about $50-75K if you raid them and $25K if you bomb them, minus the combat losses that can be VERY painful (a basic scout vehicle costs $60K to produce, and they are easy to lose). This means that in order to get a new base you need to raid about 15 UFOs with near perfect performance, and that is not considering the cost of buildings, staff and maintenance.Ground combat is pretty much the same as in the original game, except for the cover system that can sometimes be frustrating because it is not at all obvious how it calculates the lines of fire, and the game won't show you the cover calculations unless you are aiming at something.The game's performance is frankly embarrassing at times. The Geoscape scrolling is very laggy, visibility calculations cause obvious frame rate drops on larger maps, and the animations seem not to load until they are played for the first time, so the first time a new animation is shown it is basically dropped frames. This is simply unacceptable for a 2D game that is not particularly more complex than a 20 year old game that ran fine on computers compared to which your today's phone is a freaking alien planetary mainframe.Overall, the game does not really add that much to the original XCOM experience, however it recreates it quite successfully. I am finding myself returning to play just a couple more missions all the time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												This started out hard, but fun. And then psionics happened to it. For a supposedly tactical game, half your success on missions comes down to "not failing your save against psionic enemies with unlimited range and no line of sight required". You don't get psionics to throw back at them, you don't get any counters to it, and you have no idea where the attacks are coming from. Usually it's some enemy on the far end of the map, so you can't even try and rush them to remove the threat.It's not a challenge, it's just random rolls that occasionally mean half your team freezes and you waste a round. This game would have been better off without it, or limiting psionics to line of sight so you can do crazy OP tactics like "scouting" and "planning". Get XCom-Enemy Within, it uses actual game difficulty rather than arbitrarily zapping you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								Easily the best Earth defense simulator. There is a lot to love here:- Customizable soldier equipment - guns, ammo, grenades, and armor can all be fitted piece by piece- Time Units for strategic combat- Dynamic cover mechanics and shot types (snap, regular, or aimed, as well as burst fire modes)- Destructable terrain- Strategic air-to-air combat- Base Defense and Terror missions- Wide variety among difficulties (easy is a good difficulty for new players, veteran is balls-hard even for veterans, and iron-man mode is available)- Multiple bases and customizable base construction- 8 troop limit in the Chinook (or 6 troops and the armored robotic vehicle)- Many varieties of aliens which behave very differently- Challenging AI- in-battle inventory management (you can pick up the aliens' plasma rifles and grenades and use them!)- Research and production management - Hire scientists and engineers and build them dorms, labs, and workshops- A period appropriate aestheticThe bad:- Slightly clunky controls in ground missions- Cannot yet destroy parts of landed alien crafts with explosives- Lack of map variation and varying heights within mapsThese are all problems expected to be resolved by release (except the controls, which is really a minor gripe).

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is one of the best turn based strategy games I have ever played. It is very well made; I have seen no glitchs or bugs, and the controls make miss-clicks a rare occurence. The difficulty scale is great as well. At the lower levels, it is more forgiving for new players yet still really fun. At the higher difficulties, it requires a high level of both stategic and tactical knowledge to survive, providing a very satisfiying challenge that I have not seen since Civ V.The only problems I have with the game is that it does not tell how long some things may take to do, like researching tech and hiring new personel. This is a minor issue however, because after several playthroughs you have a general idea of how long these things may take to do.Overall, Xenonauts is a great strategy game (9 of 10) and is well worth playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts is a distillation of the X-COM formula to challenge veterans looking for something a little more down-to-earth than Firaxis's XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Success comes in a different package that may not be obvious to UFO Defense alumni. Veterans would think to fill their warchests by raiding landed Supply Ships and mass-producing Laser Cannons. In the Cold War, however, it's up to the funding nations to supply you - you're fighting against both time and budget constraints as you rush to research and manufacture enough new technology to have some hope of staying ahead of the alien invasion, all while keeping your neighbors happy.Ensuring the funding nations remain impressed and satisfied means spending time and resources on the Geoscape and the air game - radar coverage and interceptors. Shooting down UFOs pleases those who pay your bills; failure to effectively react to the disaster tickers is undesirable, the casualty gauge looming overhead as an ever-present reminder of the Xenonauts' reponsibilities.This also acts as something of a de-emphasis on the Battlescape: while you will want to check out new UFOs to add research options, raiding every crash site in every wave will inevitably feel grindy and the monetary rewards would take months to make a difference in the long run. Sending your top dudes to earn a few extra bucks will inevitably backfire when you lose your ace Sniper, forcing you to spend a hundred grand and two weeks to recruit her replacement and manufacture a new weapon and armor. It's much safer to sell the site to the locals, still paying for half a new Plasma Rifle while letting someone else do the dirty work, saving your vets for the new type of UFO due to appear next week.In closing, this is *the* X-COM clone we've been waiting years for. Many games have treid to replicate the formula but Xenonauts has gotten it right like no other.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Rather than write a long and somewhat scattershot review of the game I'll just say that it's excellent. It's tense and challenging. You'll see soldiers distinguish themselves in combat in terrible situations, and you'll see your vets get killed when things go sideways. You'll have to juggle the competing priorities of the air war and the ground war (hint: focus on the air war) since you can only build so much expensive stuff at once. The only glitches/bugs that really bothered me got patched (timing of bleed damage, Harridan snipers glitching into walls, berserking) and there really wasn't anything else that I feel has gone unresolved. Great game, just know that it's much more complicated than the Firaxis XCOM and will take you a lot longer to finish.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												UFO: Enemy unknown is the game i remember from my early gaming years most fondly. What can be more fun than defending earth not only strategically but tacticlly from an enemy menace?Some 20 years later this comes along. Buggy, primitive 2d graphics and lots of annoying flaws. It can be frustrating and unlikely to capture the hearts of a new generation looking for something simpler and prettier (such as firaxis attempt)But Goldhawk have been cunning and kept this game true to the original, simply improved the main areas of complaint in that original. The result is a game you just cant put down. Even the grind in the mid game remains fun as you constantly battle to get one over the alien menace.This isnt just a nicely presented puzzle like the bigger brand rival, no, this game offers up a proper tactical helping.I admit this game wont be for everyone, far from it. But imo there is no more facinating way to defend our planet against the alien menaceAnd once complete, there are some mods that transform the game into something even better. Easily one of the best games i have ever played. Thanks Goldhawk.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Having played Xcom 1, xcom 2, xcom apocalypse, xcom interceptor, ufo aftermath, ufo aftershock, ufo afterlight, extraterrestrials (have it in physical copy),xcom the bureau, xcom eu and xcom ew, AND having backed up the early access from the beginning, I must say that I don't know what to think.On one hand, it's the most accurate recreation of the classical Xcom that I've had the pleasure to play, on the other hand it's the recreation of a twenty (20) years old game.Surely it brings something new (aerial combat is good -better than I expected-), but the game quickly reminds me why it was so boring to play xcom more than a tactical mission per day: tactical combat is long, tactical options reduce to flank or either snipe while sending rookies to expore and to be slaughtered, and there is only one (1) mission type: kill them all ( a thing that was corrected in xcom eu where you had to evacuate, defend... even stop a train!)On top of that psiskills are gone, your troops doesn't have the chance to develop was probably the SKILL that really made the game funny.Conclusion: It's a good game being constantly revised by the developers (superb support), and a game that could be easily groundbreaking with a couple of DLC's correcting the mission variety and psipowers.100% recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19
												Better than the original XCOM? Yes - much less micromanagement, improved air combat & UIBetter than the recent XCOM reboot? Yes - ground combat much closer to the original (more realistic focus on cover and visibility), overall it feels less scripted and linearSo, the definitive version of one of the best strategy games ever made then? Yes!For those unfamiliar with the original XCOM, it's a fairly standard base management game punctuated by possibly the most tense, terrifying turn-based squad elements you'll ever play. It's arguably the greatest game created by two giants of the computer game industry, Julian Gollop & Sid Meier.The only slight criticism for me is that I preferred the droney music of the original which increased the atmosphere. Also, I'm pretty sure they've (rather naughtily) lifted sections of Ennio Morricone's score for The Thing!I also recommend downloading the free Community Edition update for more maps and improved UI. Xenonauts 2 is in production!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Xenonauts is easily the best Turn Based Tactics/Strategy game I've played in long time. I did not play the original XCOM or even the other spinoffs, so this review won't help you if you're looking at it from that perspective.We'll start with the core of the game, combat. Send your elite commandos all over the world to accomplish many different objectives. The combat is turned based, so you have plenty of time to think about your strategy, which is really important because around every corner, you're soldiers could meet their death. The better armed and usually physically stronger alien invaders have a clear advantage. If you're careless, you're dead. Customize your soldiers with gear/weapons to suite the role you want them to play and to suite your tactical preference, but watch out....when they're dead their dead for good along with all the expensive gear you may have equipped them with. You'll face many different types of enemies, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You'll need to adjust you tactics nearly every mission, depending on what you're facing and what area of the world you're in Urban/Rural/Desert/Arctic. The maps can get a little repetitive, apparently there are not that many, but there are plenty of map mods available or you can make your own.The second part of the game is managing your military, as a whole.  You begin the game facing an enemy who has a clear technological advantage, but thorugh research you can implement Alien technology for your own purposes, but it's expensive and time consuming, so chose wisly. Playing the game on normal, you'll always feel one step behind the aliens as they ramp up their invasion. You'l need to build bases to protect the nations of the world, who are funding you! Let too many aliens thorugh, an you'll lose the nation, loose too many nations game over man.I have about 40 hours in so far and I can highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys thinking tactically or strategically. It's a fun game you can play for 30 minutes at a time or settle in for a good 6 hour marathon. The combat can get a little repretive in the beginning, but as the game progresses I actually started to notice it less. I also downloaded some map mods too.I would give it 4 out of 5 and a must have for lovers of strategy.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												To put it in basic terms: If you ever played one of the original xcom games (not the new one), you will instantly recognize how this game plays.Xenonauts feels like a loveletter to the old xcom games, staying true to everything that made those games deep and adding some subtle layers here and there that only add to the gameplay value. Graphically it is also an upgrade of the old pixelated xcom games, although the art style may be offputing to those expecting the cartoony feel from xcom-unknown.The game easily gets me into that feeling where I want to play just a bit more, and just a bit more and... and suddenly it's 2 o'clock in the night and you realize you are yawning like crazy and ought to go to bed.I heartily recommend this game, and for an added bonus, in the options you can add numbers from a list of people that backed this game on kickstarter in the hope it would become what it suceeded in. So feel free to add soldier number 91 to your squad for a danish addition to your xenonaut-squad while playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												EDIT - (some 20 hours of gameplay later...)Having tripled my playing time and gotten deeper into the game I have gone from 'pleased' to 'impressed'. The curve at the lower levels is pretty good. You develop your newer guns, finally build and issue some, have fun for a mission or three and then suddenly 'WHAM'! New alien to bring your ego back crashing down.The air war ramps up quickly to the extent that while you start to feel you can handle everything being thrown at you on the ground, even at EASY you get the impression you just do not have enough intercepters and you never feel completely confident about handling all of the latest swarm.Having played more I have realised there are a lot more maps then I first assumed. Still not so many that you don't start recognising previous locations from time to time, but definately enough that even after 30 hours you are fighting on areas you haven't experienced before.Lot of fun, has that 'just play for a bit longer until...' attraction that easily chews up the playing hours but again, if you are not an existing XCOM fan then this game may seem a little old school to you.(end edit)(based on v1.07 and 11 hours play on Normal)Tentative THUMBS UP.Thing to remember is this game is Xenonauts, and NOT X-COM classic with better graphics. If it was sold as X-COM Classic -HD version or something similar.What that means is that, surprise! there are differences. Bases are now only one level, the world map is 2D rather then the funky globe. Some of the starting weapons and equipment from Classic either require research or are simply not within the game.Why?Because it is a different game and let's be honest, if you think classic X-COM was better, then maybe you should go play that instead (hint, I still do - or would if it wasn't so punishingly hard!! :D )The game is a bit of a mixed bag. Some of the interfaces are very simple, some (research screen I am looking at you) are downright ugly. Combat seems easier (in that it is possible to complete the early ground missions without having half your squad KIA) and the way reports of 'strange' activities pop up on the global map is interesting. You wont spot UFOs outside your radar coverage, but by looking at the reports of corp circles and abductions you can sometimes have a good idea where to send out a patrol.Ground maps are no longer randomly generated as they were in classic. On the plus side they now look a lot better, on the down side there is no longer the tenseness of simply exploring the map to work out where the drokk you actually are. Hopefully the game will add new maps with upgrades as once you have explored a map for the first time, remembering the danger spots with weird lines of sight is reasonably easy.Slightly disappointing is that crashed UFOs are no longer massively damaged when you arrive. Player's of classic will remember turning up on a crash site to find half a wall section and some un-lootable piles of smoking scrap and can breach the craft from the gapping holes your air to air missiles made in the hull. This means that every combat seems to back down to going in through the front door. Oh well.Some of the micromanangement has been removed. Everything you can't use yourself is automatically sold, so you no longer have store rooms full of stuff you are loath to get rid of.Also slightly disappointing is the study of the corpses you bring back, which are now done automatically. Gone is the choice between removing your limited science teams from the new lazer rifles you want to develop in order to study the latest hunting trophy.So, I think this is a good game. Maybe not 'great' and maybe not the sort of thing you would be interested in as an XCOM newbie trying to work out what the fuss is about.

Xenonauts is a more logical evolution of the gameplay of the older X-Com games than the new 2015 X-Com is. It uses time-units, you can pick up stuff from the ground or put it down, take weapons off dead enemies, etc. There is actual gameplay on the geoscape, multiple bases, etc.It adds a interceptor minigame that's decent, and for the most part removes annoying psionics. content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												THIS was the X-COM 'sequel' I was hoping for.  I absolutely love this game.I love the 70/80's style graphics.  It really adds a nice feel to the game.  They are finely detailed, not intentionally dated as seems to be the trend with indie games now a days.  And anyone who has tried modding the unit graphics knows what sort of attention was put into these!That brings me to my favorite thing about this:  Modding!  Man, you can change virtually anything and everything in the game if you know where to look.  Add entire tiers of weapons or armor, including their 'pedia pages.  Change the stats on weapons, how your guys level up, you name it!  I even created a dart gun mod that is currently over on their official webpage.I think the biggest con, if I had to pick one, is that it is done in the Diner Dash engine.  This apparently severely limited what the developer could do with it.  But even with that limitation, Chris still came through with an absolutely stunning game.If you like the old X-COM games, You should enjoy this.  It is well worth the money, I promise!

Posted: July 8, 2014
												This is not a recreation of the original xcom. This is an improvement. Everything is a complete improvement. Instead of sending out lone interceptors to fight off lone ufos you are able to send multiple fighters after a ufo and its escorts. It also gives concrete reasons for the invasion starting off so slowly. The ufo's are not suitable for atmospheric flight and must be modified and the smaller the ufo the faster and easier the modification. It also expanded on the variety of weapons you can equip your soldiers and the utility of other weapons. For example stun gas rockets and the addition of suppressive fire giving lmgs a more significant purpose than being extra powerful rifles.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Xenonauts does a great job of hitting that sweet spot where they've managed to significantly improve upon the original XCom games without losing the essential essence of them. They clean up and improve the UI substantially, giving you data you didn't have in the 90s like hit probabilities. They revamp and scrub the game's economy, eliminating some of the easier ways to get money, forcing you to rely much more on maintaining good relationships with world governments. They revamp the research tree, making the progression of technologies more sensible and less vulnerable to work-arounds. They tweak the combat system, adding new weapon and equipment types so that much more strategy has to go into your soldiers' layouts.Even with all these changes, this is the game I loved back in the day--or maybe better yet, it's the game I never even dreamed XCom could have been. Anyone who liked the original XCom should definitely try this game. Younger gamers who don't remember the original may find this game too challenging or not flashy enough, but strategy enthusiasts should give this game a try as well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												What a fond drive down memory lane this game is. For those of us old enough to remember the original X-com, this game will bring back happy and deliciously frustrating memories of that wonderful classic. What the current bearers of the X-com flame have failed to deliver,  the makers of Xenonauts have. We don't need a cheesey 1950's gimmick, or a story line that no one really cares about. We just want to play turn based combat with aliens like we had in the old days. The original X-com was frustrating, easy to get into, yet difficult to master and insanely addictive, Xenonauts is all of that, and more.   This game gives the gamer hours of deep strategic thinking, but without the tedious busy work of many other strategy games. You build your bases, improve your technology, hire and fire researchers, engineers and soldier, try your best to manage your budget (which is more important than one would assume), and all of this while fighting for humanity's very survival, on interesting battlefields all over the globe.     This game is wonderful for those of us who stayed up until dawn in the 90's playing the original, and for younger or newer gamers who want to have that same experience. Take it from an old school PC gamer, if you want all of the fun of the good old DoS days, but with a bit of a graphic and processing revamp, this is it.
