												Let's see, how to explain the awesome that is this this xcom knock off (Yes, it's a knock off, but a GOOD one!). If you liked Enemy Unknown and never played an XCOM game in the past, this might not be for you. If you DID play the old XCOMs and liked them, this is for you. Comparing this to Enemy Uknown, it takes away the watered down feel and brings back all the management complicity that made the older XCOM titles awesome. Don't get me wrong I loved Enemy Unknown, but whereas EU is more focused on action and less on micromanagement of your orginization, Xenonauts basically brings back the full spectrum management feel. Right down to the base building, research, combat, interceptions, etc. It just feels more robust than EU and more like the old XCOMs I loved. Thats my take on it anyway. IMO worth the buy and a good SP time killing machine.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												I was pretty late to the X-COM scene, not discovering it until around 2006 or 2007 when a friend insisted I play it. It was not too long before the very unforgiving game won me over. I fell in love with the immense freedom it gave the player on the battlefield. Often rewarding inventive methods of defeating enemies, be it through altering the landscape around you or  experimenting with different load-outs and teams. The ability to build, manage, and defend bases all while balancing available resources was intriguing and rewarding. And naturally the ability to rename soldiers/sacrifices added immense entertainment value as well. Needless to say, I was suitably impressed!With the arrival of the Firaxis version, “Enemy Unknown”, I was skeptical. I learned they had removed many of the mechanics and features I had enjoyed so much in the original. After reading glowing reviews, I finally bit the bullet and picked up while on sale. And I was not disappointed! I still lamented the loss of the of the freedom I enjoyed in the original. However, I found that Firaxis had (in my opinion) made it a far more approachable and user friendly game than the original had been. With flashy graphics and enjoyable combat, it was a pleasurable experience. But all the same, I still missed many of the features from the original which had captured my imagination.Xenonauts came as a bit of a surprise to me though. At first glance it appeared to be no more than a clone of the original X-COM with updated graphics (which initially I was not very impressed by).  And for quite some time I ignored its development. Incidentally it was the same friend who introduced me to the franchise that suggested I try out Xenonauts. After well of 80 hours I can safely say it was a great experience and truly worth successor.The story is very well done. It is surprisingly compelling, and during my first play through I found the progression through the story to be quite exciting as a result. The base building, defense, and geoscape are a fine return to the series roots. You can once again build as many bases as you wish, and optimize them in whatever ways you see fit. The tech tree is also really impressive, beginning with cold war technology, you advance quite steadily into far more lethal technologies. The aliens themselves are well designed and enjoyable (for the most part) to fight. Even the art style which I initially disliked had grown on me. The aesthetic of the aliens, weapons, ships, backgrounds, technology/lore updates are all exceptional and help keep the player engaged.To top everything off, there is a healthy modding community. Often times if you have an issue with the core game, there is a mod out there somewhere which addresses it.Xenonauts is outstanding, and I highly recommend checking it out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												The original X-COM series (Enemy Unknown, Terror from the Deep, and even Apocalypse) were among the most-immersive, deeply-strategic, and thematically-beautiful games of the 1990s. 2012's reboot was fun, but it failed to capture the sophistication and complexity of the original: it lacked the ability to perform micro-customisation upon your soldiers (Want a strong guy whose job is just to carry ammo for everybody else? That's fine!), bases ("Science" base at a secret location, surrounded by interceptor bases? No problem!), or mission strategy (Plan to fight a retreat back to the dropship, dragging the bodies of the stunned aliens with you for later research, losing the battle but advancing the war? Go on then!). And it suffered, for it.Xenonauts, however, takes the genre back where it belongs: gritty, strategic, and with every game completely unique. More-impressively, it does so in a world that's subtly-different from that of the original series: starting deep in the Cold War, and with aliens whose motivation and strategy is innovative and new, even to fans of the original series.It's not perfect: you'll read science reports that make reference to weapons you haven't yet invented, because you're doing things in the "wrong" order... but at least the game lets you do things in the order that makes most-sense to you! I'd have enjoyed being able to use alien psionics against them, as you can in the original series (and even in the reboot), but (unless I simply missed out on the appropriate research opportunities), that's sadly absent. And there are a few bugs, although I didn't come across any game-breaking ones.But what Xenonauts is is one of the best strategy games I've seen in recent years. Whether you loved the original X-COM series, or the reboot, or didn't play either... it's got something for you to enjoy. Go play it, Commander.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Spiffing! As everyone knows, unlike the reimaged XCom that came out recently, this Xenonauts is an update of the original Xcom. And it's very well done. You have the base management. Placing bases for their radar coverage, with hangars to send ships out to intercept alien craft. Then send in your landing vehicle for your troops and maybe a buggy to go round gunning down the survivors of the crashed alien craft. Could also be going in to a Terror Mission. To fight off the aliens and save what locals you can and maintain relations with the nation so terrorised. Might be the alliens attack your base and gun batteries you've chosen to build may or may not be enough, and then have to clear your base of aliens the hard way. Could be you discover a base the aliens have set up. Going in to clear it room by room.The base management leaves a lot of room for playstyles and mistakes. Setting up labs and workrooms for scientists to research alien tech and engineers to make new toys. So many toys. Found it best to keep the enhanced workshop action at the base your soldiers come home to, other bases wouldn't have access to the alien materials unless you start sending parcels of items back and forth. Extra radar arrays widen the coverage of each base, and extra bases spaced around the planets are essential in ensuring few alien craft get to run amok without you sending in your ships.When you do that, you can choose to send 1-3 ships all together. So that requires you building hangers at various bases around the world too. When  your ships catch an alien craft it gives you a % of success for an automated dogfight, but you can elect to go in to manually direct the aero-action. When an alien craft is downed you can send in your foot troops, or, just have an airstrike deal alien stragglers. Youll get a bt of money that way but no chance of acquiring fancy alien tech to play with. The land battle is as ever a turn based game.  Your mooks have a number of points they can spend on moving, kneeling, turning, shooting, luzzing grenades, equipping the med pack from your backpack to use on a wounded ally, or battering an alien over the head with a stun rod. With shooting there's a few choices in how accurate you're prepared to be, more accuracy costs more points. Cover reduces the ahcne of success while kneeling raises it. You could leave your mook with points unspent in which case they're stood there prepared to fire at any alien bugger that hoves into view. Their reflexes stat comes into play then, whether they get a shot off before the alien does. Stats like those and strength (covers how much you can carry without movement penalties) and bravery are automatically improved when they're used. So it really hurts if someone dies. If a xenonaut is hit and hurt they'll spend some time in the med-bay you built. Dead ones, there's a slim chance they recover, less so the more they're hurt.It seems rather well designed. The learning curve is about right. The arms race between you and the aliens is in your favour if you get on top of R&D early on and keep it flowing. One of your more beloved xenonauts taking a powerful hit and dying can really sting though. You could be brave and suck it up, or go back to a previous save point. It quite a moddable game in regards "numbers", so you could adjust such things as the amount of money here or there if you want. It wouldn't affect the current game, just the next one started.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												This is X-Com UFO defense 2.0If Wasteland 2 is to Fallout, then Xenonaughts is to X-com UFO defense.You get updated graphics and some minor improvements on the original.  The designer of this game must have logged many hours in Ufo defense and Terror from the Deep because I found the controls to be better than the originals.  I don't recall so many hotkeys being available to speed up the tedium of mouse clicking for 100's of UFO recovery missions, but its in here.I also like that practically every tactical mission has NPC humans, rather than just terror missions.  There are also NPC combatants that manage to bag a few every now and again.When I read about the interactive air interdiction I got excited; however, I haven't figured out how to play it.  If I autoresolve I have a 100% chance of downing an aircraft.  If I manually try my ♥♥♥♥ dies on me.  I'm not doggin it; I'm just saying that it bring a new element that challenged me.  For now, however, I'd rather do the autoresolve thing.How does it compare to Xcom Enemy Unknown?  This is more refined.  We don't have mass appeal stuff thrown in like video cutscenes and cheesy stereotype dialogues (e.g., there is no metro-smexual tension between Dr. Tittsus and P.E. Dr. Bigcuck).  Don't get me wrong; I really enjoyed Xcom Enemy Unknown, but Xenonauts is the true tribute to the original.  It doesn't sell out and try to be fancy.  It is humble, stark, and as forgiving as the orginal.What else can I say?  I have a feeling that I will be playing this version from now on.  Like I said, this is Xcom 2.0.  Why play 1,0 ever again?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Very good remake of original X-Com. Not as deep in every way, but very addicting, challenging and just a joy to play if you're a fan of the series and were disappointed in streamlined Firaxis' take on the franchise.New air combat is fun and satisfying, once you manage to win without losses when the game predicted the squadron stood no chance. UFO spotting is also a great addition to the game, providing both useful information and better immersion into the game thanks to neat news feed. I also like how the progression affects the way the base looks, adding high tech gadgets to backgrounds and characters.While I wasn't a fan of the art direction of the game, sprites are well drawn and design are interesting, music is quite decent too, especially night tracks, adding even more atmosphere to already tense night missions, probably for the first time done right since UFO Defense / TFTD. Different UFOs, alien bases and terror missions, destroyable environments, most things X-Com fan loves is here.Not everything is perfect, though. Research tree feels too linear, economy and base management are lacking because there's no need to buy/manufacture new aircraft weapons and conventional equipment for troops, everything is given for free or upgrades automatically. Alien research giving 10% bonus to damage for some reason also reeks of XCOM. Manufacturing was also completely killed, with products selling for only half a price on the market, after your engineer wasting unique materials and time on production. While I understand that it was made to fix the "OPness" manufacturing had in original games, but not only it makes no sense, it also makes manufacturing a waste of money once you unlock next tier of equipment and previous gear becomes more or less obsolete. Since both labs/engineering and living quarters require a lot of space and support only 15 people, unlike ~50 in original game + more space for building in bases, the game could still be balanced if there was at least some profit in manufacture. Battlescape also has its share of problems, with some badly designed choke points in small UFOs, UFO assault being a game of peek-a-boo with aliens by using door controls, some maps that repeat over and over again, enemies psi-attacking your troops even without having a line of sight on them, and very bad ballistics that remind me more of terrible RNG XCOM combat, and occasional shenanigans like bullet from sniper on third floor being blocked by car parked in the line on sight half way to the target on ground level. 20 years after release of original X-Com no game (aside from Silent Storm) can still replicate its proper ballistics, and it's a damn shame. And the lack of 3D geoscape is a shame too, but nothing you can do about it, engine is fully 2D, and project lead already said that this engine was a bad idea to begin with.But all in all, Xenonauts is the first game I could actually call a proper remake to X-Com. If you love X-Com and didn't like the simplicity of XCOM, then definitely give Xenonauts a go.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												If you loved the original X-Com, you will like this game a lot.This game can be rather unforgiving if you're not well versed in the old games. The X-Com reboot is but a pale shadow of what this game is. (That's not to say X-Com wasn't fun. It totally was).Xenonauts will test your patience in the battlefield as well as your tactical senses. If you're impatient and charge in, you'll be replacing soldiers more often than not. If you decide to make a beeline to the UFO, you could get blindsided by aliens you didn't see.Outside of the actual battlefield and into the Global Map, there are a fair few choices as well. Research is all important so that you begin to level the playing field between you an the aliens. You will also need to decide whether or not to expand quickly or build up your current base and its forces. There are bonuses but also negative points to this. A new base means more coverage, happier nations, more UFOs to tag, etc, but then you have to juggle this with the costs involved with running a new base. Because of the depth this game offers, this game is a welcome sight to strategy veterans.

												The original X-COM series (Enemy Unknown, Terror from the Deep, and even Apocalypse) were among the most-immersive, deeply-strategic, and thematically-beautiful games of the 1990s. 2012's reboot was fun, but it failed to capture the sophistication and complexity of the original: it lacked the ability to perform micro-customisation upon your soldiers (Want a strong guy whose job is just to carry ammo for everybody else? That's fine!), bases ("Science" base at a secret location, surrounded by interceptor bases? No problem!), or mission strategy (Plan to fight a retreat back to the dropship, dragging the bodies of the stunned aliens with you for later research, losing the battle but advancing the war? Go on then!). And it suffered, for it.Xenonauts, however, takes the genre back where it belongs: gritty, strategic, and with every game completely unique. More-impressively, it does so in a world that's subtly-different from that of the original series: starting deep in the Cold War, and with aliens whose motivation and strategy is innovative and new, even to fans of the original series.It's not perfect: you'll read science reports that make reference to weapons you haven't yet invented, because you're doing things in the "wrong" order... but at least the game lets you do things in the order that makes most-sense to you! I'd have enjoyed being able to use alien psionics against them, as you can in the original series (and even in the reboot), but (unless I simply missed out on the appropriate research opportunities), that's sadly absent. And there are a few bugs, although I didn't come across any game-breaking ones.But what Xenonauts is is one of the best strategy games I've seen in recent years. Whether you loved the original X-COM series, or the reboot, or didn't play either... it's got something for you to enjoy. Go play it, Commander.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've played thousands of hours of old X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse), and over 500 hours of Enemy Unknown/Within.  I'm enjoying Xenonauts tremendously.  Details follow, but if you're a fan of the old-school X-COM games, I'm already telling you that you should check this game out.Xenonauts describes itself as a "spiritual successor" to X-COM.  It's important to note that they were very probably not talking about Enemy Unknown/Within; the differences in polish will disappoint you if you're expecting that level of visual quality.  However, as a successor to -old- X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse) it succeeds pretty brilliantly.The look and feel of the Geoscape is very UFOD/TFTD (only much prettier), while the tactical aesthetics are much more like Apocalypse turn-based mode.  Bases have radar ranges determined by the number and quality of detection facilities present, but the range limits are far more visible than in previous games.  This makes it far easier to understand the coverage consequences of base placement. Ship Combat:  X-COM ship fights (even in EU/EW) are like sumo wrestling.  The ships' locations on the field are completely abstracted away, and there are hit percentages simulating mobility, so you see two craft holding relatively still and slugging at each other.  Misses look more like bad aiming than evasive action.In Xenonauts, the ship combat display is a 2D grid wherein momentum and turning radius count.  Weapons have ranges and firing arcs, ammo and fuel count, afterburners are a thing (but see: fuel counts) and missiles have their own maneuverability values.  Defensive maneuvers exist for evasive actions, and a dogfight isn't always 1:1 -- in fact, encounters can get up to 3 vs. 3 in some cases; as UFO's begin to appear with escorts, and fighter squadrons roam in packs daring your interceptors to come out and play, you respond by sending attack groups instead of lone planes.  There are light and heavy interceptor classes, with maneuverability, range and armament consequences.  You can't form an attack group out of craft from more than one base, unfortunately.  I'd have loved to see a rendezvous point system wherein disparate fleets could join up, but ship combat is a fun, complex mini-game in and of itself and a strategy guide could be (and probably has been) written just for that facet of gameplay.  NOTE:  There are -way- more UFO's in the early part of the game than in any iteration of X-COM.  This becomes important during...Ship Combat Aftermath:You can send troops to fight at a crash site, but that's not always an option.  You probably don't have enough strike teams to cover every site where you've shot something down, especially early on when a single Condor is still a match for anything the aliens field.  Rather than letting the sites rot and taking a PR penalty with the nation where they crashed, Xenonauts provides the option to call an airstrike and saturate that area, then send a non-combatant cleanup team to salvage what it can.  This results in a static amount of cash based on the class of crashed craft, and a few recoverable items, but no soldier experience or personnel equipment captures.Soldier Management:  Enemy Unknown/Within introduced the concept of soldier classes; a Rookie, upon promotion to Squaddie, was assigned one of four classes.  That class distinction determined what stats increased when the soldier was promoted, what weapons the soldier was allowed to carry, and what special abilities became available to that soldier as rank increased.  It's a novel concept, but there are downsides.  Class assignment is for life, for one thing, and there's little room for creative misuse of inventory -- you can't load down an Assault trooper with grenades, for instance.  Nonlethal weapons were considered Items rather than weapons in EU/EW, as well, which meant that you had to choose between that and grenades, or extra armor, or whatever else.  It added importance to the range of choices, but only by limiting them. Xenonauts doesn't have classes, but it does allow you to assign a soldier a role.  The main differences are that any role can technically carry any equipment; there are customizable default equipment templates for each role; you can change a soldier's role in the barracks anytime the soldier is on base; and you can create new roles.  Weapon disparity is a little wider, and there is in fact a "laser shotgun" and other mechanics-only nonsense, but in general the strategic and tactical choices you can make in Xenonauts is far wider and more granular than in its ancestors.Tactical Combat:Oh, man.  Where to start.  Quick list of things that don't require explanation:- Stun rockets are a thing.  You get them as soon as you get stun grenades.- You don't have to wait half the game to get stun grenades.- Nonlethal melee weapons exist, and they're weapons -- not some other item class.- All soldiers carry an infinite number of flares!  (But vehicles don't.)- Vision arcs are back.  An unarmored human has a 90-degree effective vision arc.  (Heavy armor can reduce this.)- Cover is not a light switch like in EU/EW, but rather a stack of calculated obstruction percentages like in older X-COM titles.  Stuff that might require some more description:- Range matters a lot.  Different weapons are optimized either for long-range armor-piercing fire, or massive trauma at point-blank range.  You have to make sure you send the right soldier for the right tactical situation, all the time; the aliens are as merciless as they ever were in TFTD, and a soldier caught at a disadvantage is very probably toast.- Area denial is a real thing.  Enough shell-shock (automatic weapons fire, explosives, etc.) in the immediate vicinity of a soldier (human or enemy) can cause them to become Suppressed, which takes away their TU's (no reaction fire from that soldier), and reduces the TU's they get next turn by 50% (no burst fire, probably no grenades, just movement adjustments OR one decent shot).  Heavy weapons and vehicle weapons are wonderful for this, but remember ammo is being counted.- Reaction fire is not solely a function of the reacting soldiers' statistics -- reaction initiative is calculated using (get this) modifiers determined by the weapons and equipment worn by both the active and reactive soldiers, Reaction stats, and *TU's the reacting player has left*.  That doesn't just mean that low TU's result in snap shots; it means that high TU's can result in normal or snap shots, and low TU's can lead to the reactive soldier being unable to respond fast enough even though he technically has enough TU's to take a shot.  In addition, assault weapons actually inflict a reaction penalty on anyone calculating reaction fire against them; carrying a shotgun actually makes it much more likely that you'll get the first shot in a point-blank, room-to-room encounter.Summary:The mechanics of Xenonauts are closer to what I've always wanted X-COM to be.  I'm not in love with the tactical display's graphical quality, but if there's a sequel, I'll look for that to improve.  Meanwhile, the game is a beautiful example of this game type, and the creation and maintenance of it is behavior we enthusiasts should reward by burying the developers in enough money that they decide it would be crazy not to make another one.

												Wow. Just...wow. THIS IS XCOM. This is what you've been waiting for. This is the first Xcom clone/remake/remake that I've played and felt that same old warm and gooey Xcom "feeling" that the original gave me. Get this game off your wishlist and into your library NOW, soldier!UPDATE: After getting into the late game I have come to the conclusion that this game is difficult to the point of losing the fun-factor on Veteran difficulty and impossibly hard on Insane. Still a great game, but keep in mind your sanity will truly be at stake on the two hardest difficulty levels.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												The best modern remake of X-com: UFO Defense and Terror From The Deep. It's the one most faithful to the old games.+ Improved interface/GUI, e.g. aiming interface is more like Jagged Alliance: right-click to improve accuracy.+ New air combat system that's much more fun.+ Eerie/Horror soundtrack similar to original games.+ Ground combat requires new tactics, e.g. grenades were nerfed, there is a suppression system.+ As in X-Com Apocalypse, you need to require live aliens and explosives destroy aliens bodies and equipment. So, it's more challenging to get live aliens.+ Improved graphics. Xenonauts and aliens animations are really fluid.+ So far (3rd month in the game), you can't seem to make money by creating items like in the old games. Your main source of income are the funding from the nations. Might be a minus for you.+ Quickstart guide and in-game tooltips lets you get started playing in no time.+ Geoscape now shows UFO events throughout the world, so you don't need to mess around with the cumbersome UFO Activity Graph like in the older games.+ Devs are still updating the game.+ The story and xenopedia entries are very well written.+ You can now air strike a UFO crash site for money, if you don't want/can't do the mission at the moment.+ Soundtrack and other goodies are included in the extras folder.+ Game is easily moddable.+/- Some parts of the game were simplified, but overall it still retains the essence of the original X-Com games. Some of those simplifications were: unlimited *basic* ammo/weapons, a single warehouse holds unlimited items, unlimited flares for night missions, buildings like missile defenses and some items like medkits are auto upgraded after research is done, alien items are sold/destroyed/stored automatically after a ground mission, soldiers don't have an energy meter.- Can't throw equipment to teammates. Have to drop it on the ground and have the other one pick it up.- I found the machinegun to be really useless.- Downed UFOs can only be entered through main door. You can't blow up any part of the hull, however you can still blow up the door.- Apparently, there is no incendiary ammo, particle disturbance grenade and particle sensor.Overall, the game is great! A must buy for X-Com fans.

												To put it in basic terms: If you ever played one of the original xcom games (not the new one), you will instantly recognize how this game plays.Xenonauts feels like a loveletter to the old xcom games, staying true to everything that made those games deep and adding some subtle layers here and there that only add to the gameplay value. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Xenonauts is a distillation of the X-COM formula to challenge veterans looking for something a little more down-to-earth than Firaxis's XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Success comes in a different package that may not be obvious to UFO Defense alumni. Veterans would think to fill their warchests by raiding landed Supply Ships and mass-producing Laser Cannons. In the Cold War, however, it's up to the funding nations to supply you - you're fighting against both time and budget constraints as you rush to research and manufacture enough new technology to have some hope of staying ahead of the alien invasion, all while keeping your neighbors happy.Ensuring the funding nations remain impressed and satisfied means spending time and resources on the Geoscape and the air game - radar coverage and interceptors. Shooting down UFOs pleases those who pay your bills; failure to effectively react to the disaster tickers is undesirable, the casualty gauge looming overhead as an ever-present reminder of the Xenonauts' reponsibilities.This also acts as something of a de-emphasis on the Battlescape: while you will want to check out new UFOs to add research options, raiding every crash site in every wave will inevitably feel grindy and the monetary rewards would take months to make a difference in the long run. Sending your top dudes to earn a few extra bucks will inevitably backfire when you lose your ace Sniper, forcing you to spend a hundred grand and two weeks to recruit her replacement and manufacture a new weapon and armor. It's much safer to sell the site to the locals, still paying for half a new Plasma Rifle while letting someone else do the dirty work, saving your vets for the new type of UFO due to appear next week.In closing, this is *the* X-COM clone we've been waiting years for. Many games have treid to replicate the formula but Xenonauts has gotten it right like no other.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Finally! Xenonauts replaces the original X-Com for me! The remake by fraxis didn't but I like it for separate reasons (like the Bureau). The game can be a little long the first play through since you dont' know what your doing, and the geo strategy game can be brutal. There are also a few bugs, but most of them are harmless. The end game has one that's crops up every once in a while, that requires you to reload.  The graphics a good for a indie project, but not state of the art. Despite the downsides, this is the modern X-Com! It adds a lot of new twists,  I love the strategic depth of Xenonauts, managing multiple aircraft in dogfights with UFO's. Truth is,  I didn't immediately realize the tactical depth in this when I first started playing, but after a few hours I realized it had more depth (and control) than I initially relaized.I also loved the addition of tactical shields to your teams arsenal, makes a new tactical element to your teams, and being able to set up defeault equipment for a role, or create a new role, or a hundred other small improvements over X-Com really show how Xenonauts isnt just a clone, but a player that sets a new bar.I love the armed civillians,  Billy Bob on his farm with a shotgun killing the aliens for probing his cows. The local cop who saved my beacon in a  tough fight. The military that shows up later in the game armed with the laser rifles I supplied them with, now helping my team out (somewhat). I loved my predator armor that could walk through walls and obstacles. I really enjoyed setting off several chain explosions with my explosives and firefights that clears large portions of the map! I'm really impressed with this game! It really is the ultimate X-Com homage. Its going to be tough for me to try other indie efforts after this unless they bring something vastly new to the table. Others have come close, but Xenonauts gets enough of it right to take the mantle. I hope some aspiring moder converts it to the original X-Com with the included modding tools. I would so play that mod!There is also a lot more under the hood that could be used. Some modder created a nice wav collection that realty amped up the tactical combat with lots of military chatter, lots of mods already and can't wait to see where this is in a year.

												This game has the same feel as the original X-Com, much more so than the Firaxis remake. While the remake has a small team, they tend to feel more like some sort of action movie super team. In Xenonauts, your team dies. And dies. And dies some more. When you reveal the map, you only increase the tension for those places still hidden, the awareness growing that as you eliminate hiding places you are only closing the range and make it easier for the unknown enemies to perforate your squad with vastly superior firepower. The fire superiority enjoyed by your foes makes no difference to the mission generator, often outnumbering your soldiers as well. You deliberately harden your heart to avoid becoming too attached to that one officer who can move a quarter way across the map and still have time units and accuracy to put a shot through an alien's eye because you know it's just a matter of time until...BANG! And your favorite is a crumpled corpse on the ground, not even identified by name.Then you finish the mission (if it's not a total wipe), go back to base, and hire some more, ready to do it again.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I haven't played much of the game myself, as my time played on record suggests (1.6 hrs as of December 2, 2014); however, I've seen and learned a great deal about it through YouTube videos. This is what I get out of playing the game after being totally new to the turn-based strategy genre with the exception of an hour on XCOM: Enemy Unknown:Firstly, this game is not easy for newcomers- unless you have a natural talent, in which case you should be alright. Despite this difficulty, the game poses a very interesting (and certainly frustrating) challenge if you let it do so. Small decisions count as much as most big ones- big decisions are just more obvious and, at times, more crippling. Secondly, the concepts that the game introduces are simply awesome- that is, they literally made me look to the internet to see how far along the current world powers are in terms of railguns becoming more mobile. The game does explain some of the "science" behind the magic, but beware the pseudoscience behind some of the tech. I could actually type for hours about the sheer joy I get from crushing the skulls of the fallen caesans and other ETs with a tank. Intruiging story, wonderous imagination fuel, and not-terrible-but-not-like-Unknown/Within graphics. A creepier invasion for the "braver" player. Overall, a good buy for those interested in the genres of sci-fi and strategy, but definitely not for those who can't handle a crushing defeat every now and then. Probably a good Christmas/B-day gift for some friends.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												   Remember playing X-Com: UFO Defense way back in the day?  (Not the console remake.  The real X-Com.)  Remember how cool it was?  Remember how everything was just mysterious and cutting edge?  Yeah.  Great wasn't it?  Tried it recently?   I played it recently and... Um... *Sigh*  Yeah.   So Xenonauts is like the lens through which we remember the original X-Com's greatness.  Yes, it is almost exactly the same game,,, with all (ok... most) of the flaws removed and some needed modern bells and whistles added.  Seriously.  If you like the way you remember how X-Com was, way back when.  Do yourself a favor and DON'T play it now.  Play this instead.  Keep your happy memories in tact.  ...And if you didn't play X-Com: UFO Defense way back in the day...  Xenonauts is a combination base building and turn based strategy game with a hint of real time strategy and economics thrown in.  And it works.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
TL;DR VersionIf you were a fan of the original series, get this game. If you're new to the genre, you may have some trouble.Pros: Base Building. Deeper simulation. Solid tactical experience. Sweeter learning curve.Cons: Virtually No tutorial or guidance. Have to save a lot. Air-to-air combat mechanics are funky.Full VersionIt's almost impossible to talk about this game without comparing it to the latest X-COM remake, so I appologize for that. While the new X-COM feels like a modernized interpretation of the series, Xenonauts feels like a direct modernized sequal to the original series. If you're a fan of the original, it'll feel very similar, but you'll notice a number of subtle design improvements which are virtually impossible to detail here.Ground combat feels pretty solid and similar to the X-COM series. The cover mechanics take a little getting used to, but the UI is quite straight forward. As with all X-COM games, there's still perma-death for any unfortunate soldiers. If you're a hardcore simulation fan, you'll enjoy the difficulty. If you're like me, and can't stand the loss of your beloved soldiers, you're going to have to save and load a lot. This makes for a bit of a stutter-stop experience, but from having loved the original series and the remake, I'm pretty used to it.Xenonauts uses an "action points" system similar to the original, that determines how much stuff each of your units can do per round. This inclueds the usual move-n-shoot, but also encapsulates rooting around in your inventory, crouching, reloading, and so forth. Conversely, the X-COM remake did away with this sytem in order to steamline the ground combat mechanics. While well executed, I appreciated the added complexity, especially around planning a soldier's loadout.Xenonauts retains most of the base management mechanics from the original X-COM series, such as base layout, inventory, and staffing. Having this added amount of customizability really adds to the sense that this is YOUR base, executing on YOUR plans to save the world. While the X-COM remake again simplified this experience deftly, I still very much enjoy the added control that Xenonauts gives back to the player.There are two major areas in which I feel Xenonauts falls short. One is the air-to-air mechanics. Now, when engaging an enemy ship, you can choose to enter this mini-game, in which you can control speed, limited maneuverability, and whether or not you want to retreat. Although you can pause the action at will, you don't have enough control of your aircraft for it to really matter. In the end, it's mostly a real-time battle. This feels like a disconnect in that the rest of the game is a tactical take-your-time-and-think-it-out type of experience. Even so, the game allows you to autoresolve these battles, so you don't need to worry about it if you're like me.It's possible that this mini-game is much richer and that I'm missing out on some key mechanics, which leads me to the next area in which Xenonauts falls short; no tutorials. There is almost no explanation of how to play the game. At some moments, such as the first time you initiate an air-to-air battle, you get a big block of text, that doesn't really tell you how to succeed. Due to the similarity with the original X-COM games, I didn't have too much of a problem figuring everything out, except when it came to brand new mechanics (ie: air combat), but I can imagine it is exponentially frustrating if you're new to the series.In the end, Xenonauts is an excellent executition of the original game complete with a mess of improvements and sweeter difficulty curve. It might not be as enjoyable if you're new to the genre, but if you loved the original, this is a must-have in your library.
